characters: GROUP AT STOVE FROM EASTERNER'S ANGLE
SCULLY AT CENTER, EASTERNER AND JOHN
FROM ANGLE OF SCULLY AND COWBOY
PAST SCULLY, STANDING, JUST BEYOND COWBOY
DOWN THE ROOM FROM SCULLY'S ANGLE
SCULLY, FROM SAME POSITION, NEW ANGLE
PAST EASTERNER TOWARD JOHNNIE BACK OF COWB
THE WHOLE TABLE FROM THE EMPTY END
THE FARMER FROM THE SWEDE'S ANGLE
THROUGH THE FRONT WINDOW OF THE MAIN ROOM
SCULLY'S HIGH RUMP AND THE LAMP
DOWN ON THE SWEDE'S VALISE AND RIGHT FOOT
THE EASTERNER AND THE COWBOY FROM SWEDE'S ANG
THE EASTERNER AND THE COWBOY FROM THE SWEDE'S
EXT. A STATION, A SMALL HOTEL, A SMALL TOWN,
EASTERNER AND COWBOY FROM SWEDE'S ANGLE
THE THREE FROM SCULLY'S STOOPED, INVESTIGAT
SWEDE FROM ANGLE OF HIS REFLECTION

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: below center:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start the rapid SOUND of a train bell. SWOOP SOUND of bel and train up suddenly two seconds before

dialogues.speaker: A TRAIN, (NITE)
dialogues.text: Instantly bring SOUNDS of train and bell up as loud as th audience can stand. A transcontinental express-train cros through r.s. to l.s. at frightening velocity. CAMERA is  pulling back from a close shot at medium height of the tr In the train's wake, a long, luminous ruche of snow is ra filling the screen, and slowly sinking, as SOUNDS dwindle o.s. As the last snow settles to the ground, and the SOUNDS di o.s., the CAMERA ends its pull-back about 12 feet off the ground in a

dialogues.speaker: THE PRAIRIE
dialogues.text: It is not snowing and the night sky is overcast but the s on the ground gives off enough light -- using infra-red i need be -- to establish the station (extreme l.s.), the h (dead center), the edge of the town (extreme r.s.). Even darkness the hotel gives off something odd and curdled. B and between these buildings, as our eyes become accustome to the darkness, we see an immense perspective of snowed  land, and a very distant low horizon against a black sky  which holds two thirds of the screen. HOLD THIS DARKNESS perhaps eight seconds Then, within a  maximum thirty seconds, the darkness alters through the l of pre-dawn, dawn, etc., to the light of late morning. At the proper early juncture, one or two small lights appear windows, and go out again. At the edge of the town, in th earliest real daylight, a man's tiny figure comes out of door and walks out of r.s. Little flags of smoke and stea sprout, compact and crisp, in the bitter air. Shading and detail become increasingly clear. The station is coal-bla its sign FORT ROMPER, is just readable. The town is mostl low, mean, frame construction -- the drab shades of tired blotting-paper. The Hotel, of a disturbing shade even in  darkness, gives off under the changing light an always mo and more sinister and unearthly fish-belly glare. Its sig PALACE HOTEL, is newish, and easy to read. It is a crummy rather frail-looking wooden building of two stories, crow by florid cornice work. Beyond these buildings we can see perhaps forty miles. Th sky is dull gray; the snow is like rice; there are farms, lonely distances apart. When high, shadowless morning light is established, the t silhouette of a man -- SCULLY -- walks briskly out of the Hotel front door and towards the station. o.s., begin and bring up SOUNDS of an overworked locomotive and a train; walks faster; bring up the SOUNDS; he trots; a somewhat  archaic locomotive, crusted and bearded with ice and snow slowing, drags on from l.s. a baggage car, a daycoach, th first of a string of boxcars; covering SCULLY as he trots stopping. As quickly as will not be be absurd, SCULLY  reappears, walking towards the Hotel, followed by the COW the EASTERNER, the SWEDE, in single file. At the same mom the CAMERA, which is centered on the hotel door, starts  towards the door at their pace, holding them within left- screen. We get at first only character by silhouette and  near-silhouette, then in more detail. SCULLY is in the lead, half-turning as he walks, to talk; short, chunky, late middle-aged. Next, the COWBOY, size a structure of John Wayne, tight city trousers, a solid blo of mackinaw, his best hat; he walks like a horseman and w the stooping, rather diffident stride of a man of his hei he carries a scarred raw-hide suitcase or a splotched Hol hide roll-grip. Next, the EASTERNER. He is small, slender bears himself well and entirely without the bumptiousness so many small men. Without at all mincing, he is more nea footed along the icy boards than the others are; he carri a briefcase and a middle-sized, neutral valise, possibly  with faded labels on it. Last, the SWEDE: He is above ave height but stocky enough to seem shorter than he is, and  disturbed and scared enough, as a rule, to sag an inch or two more. A shiny black leather coat to the middle of the thighs, trousers which look as if he had on two suits of  long underwear beneath them, a cap of coarse hairy wool, sizes too small, high on his head, with earflaps which at best cannot thoroughly cover his ears. There is something shaky, equivocal and arythmic about his walking. An outsi new suitcase which looks to be covered by black oilcloth  increases his clumsiness at the knees. As these men grow out of silhouette into detail and size, and we begin to hear their SOUNDS, the CHOWF-CHOWFINGS of the locomotive, o.s., drown out these SOUNDS and the  locomotive and the train, gathering speed, cut off the me from view and then fill most of the screen, the Hotel sti jutting above. As locomotive makes r.s., the CAMERA is qu close to train and place-names, emblems and names of line swinging by, suggest the whole nation and continent in  geography and history.

dialogues.speaker: FACADE OF HOTEL
dialogues.text: The CAMERA is still creeping, lowering quietly to eye hei o.s. SOUNDS of walking on icy boards. The four men enter, in single file and in the same order, at l.s. SCULLY step pace past his door and wheels and stops abruptly, bowing  slightly and flinging out one hand in a slightly uneasy p of Mine Host and causing the others to stop or tread wate in uneasy courtesy, indulging his spiel. The CAMERA stops creeping at the same moment; they are medium close. The  EASTERNER looks quietly and curiously at the strange colo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (politely concealing  his faint nausea) I've never seen the shade before,  but once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little jealous,  but very polite) And where might that be, may I ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the legs of a kind of heron; one  of the wading birds. It's a very  strange color; there's nothing else  quite like it in Nature. It declares  the bird's position against any  background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Declares his -- does it now! Well  now, surely that's a mischievous hue  for the Almighty to paint a poor  craytcher in this murderin' world.  Declare me position indeed. Aginst  inny background. That's nicely put.  That's it in a nutshell. You kin see  the Palace Hotel for miles up the  line, all weathers, and she's starin'  like the morning star. Now didn't  ye? And do ye truly admire it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a very remarkable shade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, count on a traveled man for  connisewership! But gintlemen, may  heaven forgive me an' me guests  rattlin' their teeth on me own  doorstep. (he hurries to open  the door and wave  them past him) Come in! Come in! (to Johnnie) One twenty-two three an' -- No, line  'em up along the south corridor and  don't let the grass grow under yer  feet. Hang yer coats in here,  gintlemen, unless ye prefer to go  straight to yer rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. -- No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Let's thaw ourselves out a bit; ye  can sign up at yer layzhure. Not  that ev'ry room in me establishment  ain't as warm as toast, gintlemen,  but in weather the likes o' this, ye  should have the binifit o' the lee  o' house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. -- Of course, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now here's something, friends, ye  couldn't hope to find in the Waldorf.  Ye see? (he pours a slashing  tinkle of ice- splintery water into  the first basin) What would ye git there? (contemptuously) Shteem! Where fer the chills there's  nuthin' on earth to set the blood  hummin' agin like a bit o' nice brisk  water. (Meantime, he is  filling two more  basins) Ye don't believe me? (to the Easterner) Don't be shy! try it! You'll see. (The Easterner plunges;  the instant the water  hits his face he  utters four sharp  coughs, but he stays  at it and emerges  gasping and groping;  Scully produces a  towel he grabbed  from a shelf under  the tub and now says  with an air of great  graciousness) Yer towel, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer towel, sir. (same old towel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLLY along to the Swede, eyes downcast and shifting a li he plants his heavy fingers in the water up to their seco knuckles, and quickly withdraws them, quailing profoundly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing out the towel,  now quite draggled,  politely but with  less enthusiasm) Yer towel, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Swede sinks one finger at a time into the towel and  twists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is looking into a mirror. His skin shines as if he had used some kind of metal polish on it; he is quietly surpr and pleased. He glances down casually to see if his nails are clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also gazing into the mirror. He has the same burnished lo of metal polished. Impersonal light eyes, a little bit bo very virile and empty, fixed through most of the shot on hair, which he is tidying with a public comb. His eyes ra down, casually and impersonally across his face at the fi of the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is twisting his fingers, one by one, heavily in the to by the angle of his eyes and their surreptition, it is cl that he is very carefully watching the other three men in the mirror. At the end of the shot, Scully walks into it the Swede drops the towel beside the basin. The Swede tur for the door, Scully picks up the towel, tosses it into a cardboard box, CAMERA SWINGING as they make for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in re the towel) Thank you. (calling after them) Now just make yerselves comfortable  by the stove, gintlemen. It won't be  no time till dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start through the door.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAIN ROOM
dialogues.text: Past stove on the FARMER as he glances up and starts to e back his chair to make room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mean weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mean enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven below, last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That a fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warmed up a leetle, but it's jest  makin' fer more snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snowin' a'ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big wind acomin' too, shouldn't  wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir, shouldn't wonder if we git  us a real ole fashion' blizzard. If  ye don't mind my askin', stranger,  where might ye be from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was down to Omahaw; a little  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' where might ye be headin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got me a little ranch, up near the  Dakota line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That a fact? Stoppin' over fer the  Spur train, 's 'at right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myself, I'm a farmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. That's right. Started as a  homesteader, back in seventy-six,  but now I own muh land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quarter section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. Quarter section. When I come  here it warn't nuthin' but a untamed  wilderness like you might say. But  now I own me a quarter section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence. Farmer spits again, then addresses the Eastern

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' what might yer own business be,  stranger, if ye don't mind my askin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all, sir. I'm a journalist.  Newspaper man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now is that a fact? (carefully) Not meaning no offense, you're from  the east, ain't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Yes. (against his natural  reticence) A Philadelphia paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right now. Well, not meanin'  no offense, I'm mighty glad to hear  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Why's that, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was skeered ye might be from Noo  York City. Not that I've ever laid  eyes on one, an' o' course, it could  be I heared wrong. But what ye hear  tell... (a half silent  whistling whew with  a shake of the head) ...them Noo Yorkers! (Uneasy glance at the  Swede; tactful change  of subject) But they ain't never nuthin' happens  out here, Mister, not that's fer the  nooze papers. -- Is they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you see, I'm not after news  stories just now. (politely) Back east we're all so ignorant of  the rest of the country, that's all.  I am too, and I don't like to be  ignorant. I just want to learn what  things are really like, If I can,  and tell others who don't know, you  see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chews it over,  interested but puzzled) An' they'll pay ye a livin' fer that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if ye don't mind me askin', why  how come ye coms to Rawmpr? Ain't  nuthin' ever happens here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (careful and very  polite but candid) Frankly I didn't know I was getting  off till I got here. Seeing it from  the train, I just felt I couldn't go  on by without seeing more of the  Blue Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Hotel! Oh! You mean right where  we're sett'n'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner nods, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I ain't no proper jedge, but  the woman, she thinks it's mighty  purty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw a color like it. Not on  a hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a fact now? Well I'll be  dogged. (pause. To the Swede) An' how 'bout you, Mister, if ye  don't mind me askin'? Where might  you be from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA VERTICAL over the dining table, starting at the he pulling down along the aisle of places moderately slow.  Perhaps one or two heads ad lib into the shot, ducking ov the plate for a bite, but except for this, heads are not  visible -- only what is on the table, and the busily eati and reaching hands. Subdued SOUNDS of shy, speechless, hu eating. The food is all on the table and by evidence of d done, we are well on into the meal. Voices are very spora and ad lib, possibly recognizable; close to monosyllabic wholly utilitarian except for the Easterner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meat please... Pass the potatoes...  Turnips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are passed, used and returned without comment. A han and fork reach to spear a biscuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I have the butter, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An almost inaudible "Sure," in reply and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voices are o.s., such hands as reach deeper into the  terrain than the eating plates, appear at unpredictable a and rhythms; perhaps two might also collide and spring ap with the almost electric-shock celerity of shy courtesy. more than ten seconds to this VERTICAL PULL before we beg to hit barren space, the tundra-like lower reaches of the table, all much-mended, not perfectly clean, white tablec no places set. After just a little of this, CAMERA begins tilt and settle so that as it reaches the end of the long table, (room for a crowded 14) it is at eye level of a se man looking up the center of the table at Scully at the h Along l.s., the Swede (next Scully), and Johnnie; r.s., t Cowboy, (next to Scully) then the Easterner and the Farme We pause just long enough to get a glimpse of Scully's  character through his eating: a business-like but rather  frugal and finicky eater, even a touch of old-maidishness an old fashioned and rather cute old guy; absorbed in eat he loses entirely his Mine Host mannerisms, he's just an  aging pappy at home, reloading. Rather frail eyelids and  stretched neck when he drinks water; an evidently self-ta but deeply habitual care to take small bites and to keep lips closed over his chewing; dabby with his fork; delica at harpooning a biscuit; a suggestion of dental plates wh don't quite fit.

dialogues.speaker: THE SWEDE
dialogues.text: A big napkin is tied under his ears, its knot-ends make s ears below his own. He is sweating a little. He uses his  fork left-handed and upside down, European style. He eats steadily with heavy square gestures, and we see in his ea and chewing a conflict between the hunger of a fairly hea eater and his uneasiness. He is intensely silent and his  eyes are darting all over the joint with a dog's eating- vigilance plus his own special kind of uneasiness. Elbows wide and clumsy, he usually grazes Johnnie and as CAMERA  pulls to the left losing the Swede and picking up Johnnie the elbows collide rather hard and the first we see of  Johnnie's face involves a spasm of annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: THE COWBOY FROM JOHNNIE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: The Cowboy is winking at Johnnie, amused.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNIE
dialogues.text: He watches the Swede. A small, sour smile, friendly eyes, reaction to the Cowboy. His eating is the normal fast hea eating of a not very well mannered, far from meek, kid,  exactly on the watershed between being a boy and a very y man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A napkin tucked fairly high into his dark shirt, his larg elbows held in with unaccustomed tightness. His eating sy is to mash whatever can be mashed into malleable material mix it, load his fork by help of his knife as heavy as  possible, sculpture and trim it with his knife; changes f to right hand, brings it up to a mouth which opens for it and closes over it as efficiently as a steamshovel, then  working his full jaws with a fair amount of SOUND which h keeps reasonably subdued, meanwhile lowering his fork,  changing hands, and starting all over again. He swallows  exactly as soon as the new load is ready and takes a swal of water just before shifting the fork to the right hand: solid machine-like reciprocation between knife, fork, lef hand, right hand, mouth and water glass. Otherwise, as a  rule, his eyes are either attentive to his plate, or out focus. PULL CAMERA TO THE RIGHT, losing the Cowboy and picking u the Easterner: his are the ordinary eating manners of a w brought-up middle-class Easterner, shaded by his own  considerable natural elegance. The modestly hearty appeti of a small healthy man. Small, strong, fine hands. As wit his way of speaking, he neither obtrudes nor tries to con or modify what is natural to him or to his background. He a clear master at seeing everything there is to be seen  without appearing to stare, or to sneak glances, or even look, or even to be careful not to look. As the CAMERA le him, PULLING RIGHT, he touches his mouth with his napkin, which has been in his lap. TAIL OFF briefly on the Farmer, napkin tucked broad over of overalls, hard, heavy-knuckled red-looking hands: look at nobody; hoeing it in; an aging, hard working countryma at home at this table, and unself-conscious of strangers.

dialogues.speaker: THE WHOLE TABLE FROM THE EMPTY END
dialogues.text: They are all eating slower, the tail-end of the meal. AD and unobtrusively behind this, is Scully's daughter movin waiting on table, silently. She is a pale, melancholic, p once-pretty spinster of about 30. By-play and reaction be her and the diners should be present but minimal, and pla ad lib in passing, never pointed up. Scully rearranges himself to lean back in his chair and p his hands on the table. A heavy silence as they dab at th food.

dialogues.speaker: THE SWEDE
dialogues.text: His eyes angle sharply to the Cowboy and then to the  Easterner.

dialogues.speaker: THE EASTERNER AND THE COWBOY FROM SWEDE'S ANG
dialogues.text: The Easterner catches the Swede's eye, looks quickly down The Cowboy's eyes up; down. The Easterner looks up again  with an inevitable tinge of surreptition.

dialogues.speaker: THE SWEDE
dialogues.text: The Swede is disturbed by the Easterner's look; glances  sharply to the Cowboy.

dialogues.speaker: THE EASTERNER AND THE COWBOY FROM SWEDE'S ANG
dialogues.text: The Cowboy looks up with inevitable surreptition.

dialogues.speaker: THE SWEDE
dialogues.text: The Swede is still more worried. Gives Scully a sharp gla

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY FROM THE SWEDE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: He looks up at the worried look, quickly down again; up a slyly.

dialogues.speaker: THE SWEDE
dialogues.text: Eyes sidelong to Johnnie, very sly and worried, then to t Easterner and the Cowboy, intensely suspicious and deeply worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy looks up in flat perplexity; the Easterner loo up in curiosity so veiled it looks almost criminal; then looks down; then the Easterner and the Cowboy glance towa each other, each rather secretly, checking if the other h noticed anything odd; it looks very much like complicity.

dialogues.speaker: THE SWEDE
dialogues.text: Very deeply bothered, he rakes his glance at each man in  turn, then sharply up at the wall above Scully.

dialogues.speaker: THE SWEDE
dialogues.text: The Swede's eyes leave the engraving, quick glances all a again; he is sweating. He looks into his plate and at his heavy hands on either side of it. He is working hard to b himself, he begins to get brave and to resolve himself; a last he determines to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Scully) Me, I come from New York City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Swede casts quick somber eyes at the Farmer.

dialogues.speaker: THE FARMER FROM THE SWEDE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: His fork hesitates a fraction near his mouth and goes in  fast. The Farmer looks oven more absorbedly into his plat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (juicily polite) Do ye now! Now isn't that intristin'!  Isn't that fascinatin'! A great city.  Ah a great city. Well I remember me  own arrival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come from New York too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I only seen it fer a matter of  days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The daughter passes behind them; bread pudding to each.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My home was Bahstin Mass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every one quietly starting to eat dessert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lived there ten years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin yearrs. Ye don't say. Tin years.  A great city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before that I come from Sweden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ye don't say. Fine people, the Swedes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In New York I was a tailor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tayylor! Ye don't say! A tailor ye  say. Now isn't that simply  fascinatin'. (to the table at large) The gintleman here tells me he was a  tailor. Isn't that intristin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah: tailor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well sir, tailorin' I never learned.  Ye might call me a jack of all trades  and master o' none, exceptin'  hotelkeeping... (laughs modestly,  glancing hopefully  around the table) ...but tailorin', no, that's a mystery  to me... It must be a fascinatin'  trade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dead silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard on the eyes, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (More silence; his  eyes go again to  Scully; a kind of  suspicion is in them,  and in his voice) How long you been here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourteen years this last August I  came here and I never had cause to  regret it. A good town, sir. Good  neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scully beams a little nervously, glancing around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are the crops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheat, sir. That's the main crop, ye  might say the only crop. Wheat. (Eyes and polite  gesture to angle of  Farmer) Here's a man kin tell ye all there  is to know about wheat, can't ye  Henry? Henry's a wheat farmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy and the Easterner are eating very quietly. The Farmer nods, saying nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splindid soil. Rich as cheese. Some  farms here, the yield is up to thirty- five bushels to the acre. (to the Farmer) Isn't that correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Farmer nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last summer at the best it brought  20 cents a bushel. So ye can readily  see it's a prosperous community. (A rather wretched  smile) Plain but prosperous. (More silence) There are farmers hereabouts who are  to be accounted as wealthy men. (Silence) Farmers, mind ye. (To table at large,  almost pleadingly) Wealthy!

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY FROM THE SWEDE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: Appalled, his glasses wobble on his nose. SOUND of Swede' laughter o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy's jaw hangs open as if he were dead; in the  Easterner, a far more sophisticated astonishment and  wondering; the Farmer scowls more with puzzlement than an all dead silent, hands of all three arrested; continue Sw laughter o.s.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE'S HEAD
dialogues.text: Laughing and gleaming and glinting at them in great amuse and a glitter of fear.

dialogues.speaker: FULL LENGTH OF TABLE
dialogues.text: Towards Scully. Everyone motionless and silent except the Swede, all heads gawping at him: he is rocking with laugh and quietly raising his heavy hands an inch from the tabl and slapping them down again, over and over.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE FRONT WINDOW OF THE MAIN ROOM
dialogues.text: Extreme violence of snow and wind, the only visual anchor is a blanched gate post leaning rigid into it. SOUNDS of  strong wind, shut away, and of snow against the window pa PULL BACK as Scully's aging hand releases a harsh ornate  lace curtain he has pulled back, and BACK PAST SCULLY tur his face in CLOSE UP from the window, smiling, and announ to the room at large:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real old-fashioned blizzard,  gintlemen. (Almost proprietary  about it)

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE ROOM FROM SCULLY'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: They are all filing in from the dining room past the stov in the profoundly relaxed few moments of shapeless drifti after a satisfying meal. In their whole demeanor and tone voice there is absolute security; total lack of personal  connection with the blizzard except the pleasure of being indoors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (forward along l.s.  and drifting toward  the center) I should say it is. (he continues leisurely  across the room  fishing in his pocket  for a cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy is a little behind the Easterner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure looks like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little right of center he slowly turns his back, gettin out tobacco sack and papers. The Easterner by now is ligh up. The Swede walks much more slowly, beveling almost str toward the CAMERA, deeper towards us than any of the othe eyes on angle of window; slowly prodding tobacco into his pipe. His comment is a scarcely audible breathing; in his face is already the beginning of a strange excitement as watches through the window and approaches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a strange,  private excitement,  almost a whisper) Yaahh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Farmer, meanwhile, swings in just behind the chairs a the stove. He utters the quiet gasp of total belly- satisfaction, an "ahhh" not unlike Titus Moody's to Fred  Allen, but earthier. He is loosening his belt and content fingering through a gap in his shirt to scratch his belly Johnnie is in, silent, between the chair and the stove. T Easterner starts glancing at the news headlines; the Cowb starts slowly toward the stove; the Swede continues very  ponderously and slowly toward the CAMERA and the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Johnnie! Lay on more coal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to burn the place down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner turns to face the room. CUT IN MID-TURN.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY PAST EASTERNER
dialogues.text: Advancing from the window and leaning to peer toward the  stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, it's rid hot now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes down to the middle of the room, the CAMERA with  him, losing the Swede, still talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I tell ye, friends, there's nuthin'  like a chair beside a stove...

dialogues.speaker: THE EASTERNER
dialogues.text: His eyes and head following Scully who is already out of  shot toward the stove. The Easterner is lazily and happil observant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) ...to make ye shpit 'n the eye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEDIUM SHOT -- FROM EASTERNER'S ANGLE TOWARD SCULLY and t group coalescing toward the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to CAMERA) ...o' the worst weather Heaven kin  send.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (absently; contentedly) That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The startling SOUND, o.s., of hollowed palms being clappe together.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE FROM EASTERNER'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: Pipe clenched, a queer grin on his face, just finishing h handclap of solitary excitement and pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much interested, his eyes flick from the Swede's angle to the angle of the stove and the group; the newspaper droop in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP AT STOVE FROM EASTERNER'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: They have noticed nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be off about me dooties  if you'll excuse me gintlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. So long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scully crosses up the room toward l.s. CAMERA FOLLOWING,  losing the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) How 'bout it? Ready to get skinned  alive again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, day I see you skin a gopher  I'll deed ye my farm, an' my old  woman throwed in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND of a squeaky hinge across this.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY FROM EASTERNER'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: Going through the little swinging gate by the registratio desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be good thing for your land and a  mercy for your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching the table) Jest get busy with that skinnin',  son, loud talk never proved nuthin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swinging chair into  place) I want to see this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner walks into the shot as they severally arran chairs, cards and chips and start to settle down.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Farmer sits in original position; Johnnie nearest the coa and with his back to it. They are cutting for deal and th Cowboy and the Easterner, who are doing the last necessar hiking of chairs, look on.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE FROM SAME ANGLE
dialogues.text: His rigid, leaning stance has been four feet or so from t window. He is now very close to the window and is just pu under himself a small stool. o.s. THE SOUND of the oily w of expert shuffling.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE FROM THE SAME ANGLE
dialogues.text: The window is beyond him, his eyes are fixed deep into th snow. o.s. SOUNDS of dealing and ad lib bidding. CAMERA P SLOWLY around so that the Swede is in still larger close filling most of the screen. He is looking out intensely p the CAMERA, giving tiny, rapid pulls on his pipe; his fac showing signs of an inexplicable excitement; eyes becomin almost dreamy. CAMERA SLOWLY TURNS square on the window t focus on what his eyes are fixed on, -- the post. Storm S UP and card SOUNDS FADING to inaudibility. DISSOLVE to sn higher on post and, almost immediately, A LOUD SLAPPING D OF CARDS and the Farmer's angry voice and the scrape of a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deep fright and guile in the face and a strange and malig smile.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER FROM JOHNNIE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: He is just finishing standing up, a look of heated scorn his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad. Poor feller just ought to  leave cards alone. (They nod; they are  wholly on his side) Or his temper, one or the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Ye can't afford a  temper, not if ye play much cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or cards, if you have a temper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckles) Mister, ya got sumpn' there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout a whirl at four-handed; or  do you reckon we can keep from bitin'  each other's heads off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heavy jocosity) Buster, my gun's right on the table  so don't try nuthin' fancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling with Cowboy) We might draw up a treaty of non- aggression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reckon I'll throw in with you,  Johnnie, you look like a mean man to  have agin ye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low voice) Better make sure the Swede'll play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hehnh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wondered if you'd be my par --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout a little game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uneasy but determined to show everyone that he is not afr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh? What kind of a game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High Five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some call it Cinch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't no cinch the way that poor  Farmer plays it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some call it Double Pedro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never knowed that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohh. Yaah. Double Pedro. Is that it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five o' trumps yer Pedro, five o'  same color's yer left,...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (across him) Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...ranks jest below yer five o'  trumps, each count ya ten points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yaahh. Suure I played it. (sharp pause) For money you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either way suits me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just play for fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suits me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice up) Just for fun, if that suits you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fun. Yah. Yah. I play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all pull up their chairs. The Swede laughs shrilly a strangely.

dialogues.speaker: EASTERNER FROM THE SWEDE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: He looks up quickly at the Swede (lens)

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY FROM JOHNNIE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: His jaw drops open, his head and eyes toward the Swede.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNIE FROM THE COWBOY'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: Not really looking except very quietly, 'as if from under his eyes', holding the cards with still fingers.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNIE PAST COWBOY AND EASTERNER
dialogues.text: His hands still suspended motionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's get at it. Come on now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faint nods of agreement and shiftings forward as they beg to cut for deal.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNIE'S HANDS SHUFFLING THE CARDS
dialogues.text: He is a very fast shuffler. We watch him finishing one wh and through another, then he puts the cards toward the Sw for the cut, the CAMERA FOLLOWING AND PULLING BACK. The S slowly and seriously cuts the deck three ways as the CAME RECEDES AND RISES to take in his face and Johnnie's. He i smiling at Johnnie who seems about to speak -- not quarre somely exactly -- but lets it go and starts gathering in deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnnie deals very rapidly, three cards to a man at a tim the CAMERA following the cards around and the eyes of the four men following too. The Swede picks up his first thre cards as quick as they fall, the others leave theirs on t table. He instantly takes them in so close to his chest t in looking, he is like a woman looking down the front of dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all pick up their cards and look and arrange them.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA ON COWBOY
dialogues.text: The Swede's VOICE names the trump suit.

dialogues.speaker: TABLE
dialogues.text: The players discard, face up. (They have been dealt nine  cards each). They lay them down almost simultaneously: Th Easterner 7, the Cowboy 7, the Swede 5 and Johnnie 8. The Cowboy WHISTLES softly.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE CENTERED
dialogues.text: Johnnie fills for them. 4 to the Easterner, 4 to the Cowb and 1 to the Swede.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNIE CENTERED
dialogues.text: He robs the deck for 5 cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Swede leads, Johnnie lays a card out, then the Easter then the Cowboy. The Cowboy lays his first card down quie but already his face, especially the eyes, have strangely altered. He seems essentially quite a gentle guy but the  usually rather slow eyes are bright and ruthless. THE SHO CONTINUES to the Swede as he rakes in a trick and leads h next card; past Johnnie for his and the Easterner for his the Cowboy who, with a face like the Archangel Michael go Satan, WHAMS down his card.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE, JOHNNIE, EASTERNER
dialogues.text: The instant the card hits the table with its startling no the Swede jumps with fright, is mad at being scared and f a smoldering, mean eye at the Cowboy. Johnnie is mildly startled and quietly amused, much aware the reactions of the other two. The Easterner flinches with startlement; mildly annoyed; little annoyed with himself for being annoyed; an automat and almost successful effort to show nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FROM COWBOY'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: As the hand and card WHAM down again, Johnnie's eyes go t the Cowboy, more amused. The two others take care not to  look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is on top of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND of shuffling. His face has begun to darken, swell a crease; he is looking dull daggers toward the Cowboy from under his brows; sore as a boil. It is clear the Cowboy h busted hell out of his bid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND OF cowboy's VOICE bidding. The Easterner is sizing up with care; he is a little annoyed and shaken, but a  disciplined man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is playing a card, eyes very watchful of his two oppon and still more amused. He knows how sore they are getting and how off-their-game it is putting them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still more tickled with himself and more ruthless than be WHAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullet by golly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still more so than before. WHAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reckon that'll learn ye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A card lifted high to wham, then laid out quite gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reckon we'll leave um take this-un  Johnnie-boy, sure looks like they  could use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAM on CLOSE UP OF SWEDE By now boiling internally, he  sullenly plays his card. WHAM on CLOSE UP OF EASTERNER Managing almost perfectly t control his wincing and hide his anger. WHAM on CLOSE UP OF JOHNNIE Eyes quick at Swede and the  Easterner, just managing to hold in his laughter. WHAM on CLOSE UP OF COWBOY Sweat bright on his forehead, tie and collar loosened, impervious to their anger; happy a clam. WHAM on CLOSE UP OF JOHNNIE He can no longer contain his  laughter. WHAM on CLOSE UP OF EASTERNER Looking pinched around the  nostrils and pretty sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready for the wham; a light card falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Reckon we can afford it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Swede does a quiet collapse equivalent to that of lea against a strong wind which suddenly stops; Johnnie's lau LOUDENS o.s. The Swede, still wearing coat and vest, is i great state of dishevelment, sweating hard, miserable; by now he is as mad at quiet cards as at whams and as mad at Johnnie as at the Cowboy. WHAM on CLOSE UP OF THE EASTERNER His vest unbuttoned, un to sit up straight any more; he is smiling bitterly; SOUN of Johnnie's laughter intensifies o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weak with laughter, but still at it; by now his shirt is  unbuttoned down to the waist and he is sweating with laug laughing as much at the Cowboy as at the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His large, thick, long red neck sprouting enormously from tie and collar still more awry than before; aware he too being laughed at but stolidly and hugely pleased with him eyes to all three players: WHAM. The CAMERA lifts and loses his head and shoots over it an the slickening SOUND of the cards, up the length of the r centering on the window and the wild snowing outside: ord full daylight: HOLD, fading the card SOUNDS and the laugh and the beat of wham almost to inaudibility and whiffling the blizzard SOUNDS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well into the beginning of dusk; a melancholy and slightl sinister light through the window, touching everything  visible; fade card SOUNDS in and up, and Johnnie's laught much more tired and habituated; LOWER CAMERA to take Cowb head, the kind of guy who never knows when a joke stops b a joke; another full-sized WHAM;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEDIUM SHOT -- SWEDE, JOHNNIE, EASTERNER from COWBOY'S AN Johnnie is practically sick with laughter; the other two beat-out and sick to death of it. They are almost sorer a Johnnie than at Cowboy and show it in their hangdog glanc at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haahh, Lordy, I could die laughin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Swede, and even the Easterner, flick him bitter glanc Johnnie relaxes still more limp in his chair, tears on hi cheeks, catching their hard looks and totally unmoved; ju another whicker of laughter at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Your deal Johnnie, and you'd better  give the other boys some cards for a  change. They sure look like they  could use a few.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gett'n' chilly in here. (looking up and around) Hey, it's gett'n' dark.

dialogues.speaker: FROM MIDDLE OF ROOM
dialogues.text: They all look up and around towards the window and realiz it for the first time. Johnnie gets up; behind the follow lines he puts on coal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm! (he acts bemused coming  out of deep  concentration on the  cards)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause. From mid-room, in the fading light, we watch the watching the darkening, the strange light on their faces, the faces calming, even saddening a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Snow sure does look blue, this time  a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner nods; a little surprised that Cowboy notice it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny, cause snow ain't blue, it's  white. Snow white, like they say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner smiles very quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reckon it's the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods; then all but  whispers) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Swede, throughout this, is deeply still and withdrawn his face is preparing, inconspicuously, the strange line which he will re-enter the conversation. Johnnie, finished with the stove, crosses between CAMERA the table to side table o.s., their eyes follow him quiet light changes on their faces as, o.s., he lights and turn up a lamp.

dialogues.speaker: FROM SAME POSITION
dialogues.text: As he finishes with the lamp and leaves the shot, HOLD a  moment on the lamp, its light tender and magical in the f day, and disclosing their faces, still bemused in the  ambiguous lightings of the last daylight and of lamplight in daylight. There is a soft, strange point of light in e eye.

dialogues.speaker: ON JOHNNIE
dialogues.text: Johnnie reseats himself, pulls up, and gets the deck read for shuffling; and their heads turn back from the lamp to the game. Johnnie, realizing the shift and slowing of moo and influenced by it, dawdles a little, more or less idli and toying with the cards. A deeply pleasant and comforta silence, tinged with the melancholy of dusk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beginning on the Easterner's quiet face; then the Cowboy' (past him we see the whole room and the darkening window) then the Swede whose strange eyes still catch the lamplig then Johnnie, ready to resume playing but waiting for the This shot is to crown and epitomize the mysterious yet  peaceful mood -- which is now broken by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., quiet and musing) I suppose there have been a good  many men killed in this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short, electrified pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) How's that?

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY, JOHNNIE, EASTERNER
dialogues.text: ANGLE All looking at the Swede sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes move to the Cowboy and the Easterner, then to  Johnnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, I suppose there have been a  good many men killed in this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the divil're you talkin' about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: astounded and intensely curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a blatant laugh,  full of false courage  and defiance) Oh, you know what I mean, all right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a liar if I do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very much the son of  the proprietor) Now, what might you be drivin' at,  Mister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winks at Johnnie, a  wink full of cunning) Oh, maybe you think I have been to  nowheres. Maybe you think I'm a  tenderfoot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know nuthin' about you and I  don't give a whoop where you've been.  All I got to say is I don't know  what you're drivin' at. There hain't  never been nobody killed in this  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a sudden swing of  his whole head toward  the Swede) What's wrong with you, Mister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALL FROM SWEDE'S ANGLE, AT SPEED OF FLICKING EYES: Cowboy with the Easterner in the b.g. and slightly blurred focus Johnnie with the Easterner in the b.g. and slightly blurr focus; the Easterner alone, in sharp focus; all are tight looking into the Swede's eyes but the Easterner is the on one who looks at all "concerned" or in the least sympathe

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNIE
dialogues.text: He seems to feel he is "formidably menaced". He sends an  appealing glance to the Easterner. Start very quietly, br up ever louder, o.s. SOUND of "some loose thing beating  regularly against the clapboards" -- "like a spirit tappi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mockingly, to  Easterner) They say they don't know what I mean!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impassively) I don't understand you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnnie and the Cowboy exchange glances and look to the S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Oh, I see you are all against me. I  see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the shrug, the CAMERA creeps a little to the r. pa the Easterner and bores in on the Swede and the Cowboy, t latter in deep stupefaction and rising impatience. By the time of the second "I see", the CAMERA loses the Swede  entirely and the Cowboy, in solitary CLOSE UP, slams down his hands on the board:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, what're you gett'n' at, hey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHIP CAMERA TO SWEDE AND TILT UP as he springs up with th celerity of a man escaping from a snake on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing in tilted  close up from the  angle of the center  of the table) I don't want to fight! I don't want  to fight!

dialogues.speaker: HEADS
dialogues.text: They have saved the table from his sudden getting up; the hands clench it. The Cowboy stretches his long legs insol and deliberately. He jams his hands deep in his pockets. spits, twisting past his shoulder, into the cuspidor almo at the Swede's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet and contemptuous) Well, who in tarnation thought you  did?

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE AND COWBOY
dialogues.text: The Cowboy's turned head and jaw in floor of shot at the  beginning; slowly CREEP ON THE SWEDE, gaining a little, l the Cowboy, as the Swede backs rapidly toward the wall ne the coat room, in his eyes, "the dying swan look". The TA outdoors is VERY LOUD by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice quavering) Gentlemen, I suppose I am going to  be killed before I can leave this  house! I suppose I am going to be  killed before I can leave this house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND of door opening o.s.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY, FROM SAME POSITION, NEW ANGLE
dialogues.text: He enters from his office near the front door. He pauses surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly and swiftly;  head turning to answer  Scully) These men are going to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill you! Kill you? What are you  talkin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Swede makes the "gesture of a martyr".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, Johnnie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sullen, but looking  at Scully) I dunno. I can't make no sense to  it. (eyes drifting, he  begins to shuffle  the cards with an  angry snap) He says a good many men have been  killed in this room, or something  like like that. And he says he's  goin' to be killed here too. I dunno  what ails him. He's crazy, I shouldn't  wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill you? Kill you? Man, you're off  your nut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know. I know what will happen.  Yes, I'm crazy -- yes. But I know  one thing...

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: An almost lightning quick shot of all of them from the Sw angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I know I won't get out of here  alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD on him, sweating and full of dread, at least three  seconds of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He "draws a deep breath, as if his mind was passing into last stages of dissolution".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering almost to  himself) Well, I'm doggoned.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: Wheeling suddenly on Johnnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been troublin' this man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly; with grievance) Why good night, I ain't done nothin  to 'im!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (one step forward;  stops) Gentlemen, do not disturb yourselves.  I will leave this house. I will go  away, because --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He accuses them dramatically with his glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Because I do not want to be killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wheeling, furious,  to Johnnie) Will ye tell me what's the matter ye  young divil? What's the matter,  annyhow? Speak out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blame it! I tell you I don't know.  He -- he says we want to kill him,  and that's all I know. I can't tell  what ails him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind Mr. Scully; never mind. I  will leave this house. I will go  away because I do not want to be  killed. Yes, of course, I am crazy --  yes. But I know one thing! I will go  away. I will leave this house. Never  mind, Mr. Scully; never mind. I will  go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will not go away. You will not  go away until I hear the reason of  this business. If anybody has troubled  you I will take care of him. This is  my house. You're under my roof, and  I will not allow any peaceable man  to be troubled here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind, Mr. Scully; never mind.  I know you don't want trouble, but  you can't stop them. Nobody can stop  them, not God Himself. (sad wag of head) No Mr. Scully, I will go away. I do  not wish to be killed. I'll get my  baggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen is empty for a moment, then Scully darts into shot, half across the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (peremptorily) No, no!

dialogues.speaker: SAME POSITION
dialogues.text: Angle for the Swede's "beyond words" backward glance at  Scully, and his sad and deliberate exit. Scully still transfixed in c.s., looking after the Swede; SOUND of a door closing and the Swede's slow feet on the  stairs. He holds, slowly turns, walks slowly and very  impressively back toward the table, CAMERA with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. What does this mane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rather loudly and  almost in unison) Why, we didn't do nuthin' to him!

dialogues.speaker: UP AT SCULLY
dialogues.text: So close that Johnnie and the Cowboy are not in the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) No? You didn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why this is the wildest loon I ever  see. We didn't do nuthin' at all. We  were jest sett'n' here playin' cards,  and he...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., interrupting) Mister --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solemnly) Mister: what has these boys been  doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly, after a long,  careful pause) I didn't see anything wrong at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to frame in Johnnie and the Cowboy; vindicated a little smug.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: Miserably and desperately chewing that one over: a sudden outburst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (howling) But what does it mane? (to Johnnie) I've a good mind to lather ye for  this, me boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frantic) Well what've I done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scornfully) I think you are tongue-tied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at them 1-2-3 again, turns on his heel; walks to the stairway door and out of shot, CAMERA LIFTING a trifl to follow.

dialogues.speaker: THE THREE
dialogues.text: Over SOUND of closing door and Scully's climbing feet, ea looks from one to the other, speechless, dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: THE SWEDE'S ROOM, (UPSTAIRS)
dialogues.text: The Swede's leaning left shoulder; he is strapping his va A LITTLE NOISE; he straightens up wheeling with a loud cr CAMERA following into CLOSE UP; his terrified eyes are fi just to the right of the lens.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY AT THE OPEN DOOR
dialogues.text: He is carrying a small kerosene lamp which scare-lights h wrinkled face. He should "resemble a murderer" sufficient to startle even the audience.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: Still sick with terror as Scully leaves the dark corridor and enters the lighted room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man! Man! Have you gone daffy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying his lamp; ordinary lighting of room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no! Oh, no! (short pause) There are people in this world who  know pretty nearly as much as you do --  understand?

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: On his deathly pale cheeks are two spots, "as sharply edg as if they had been carefully painted". His eyes brighten almost as if with tears. For a moment his mouth trembles; then he makes it firm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet, solemn,  profoundly sad) Just one rule, Mr. Scully, and I  learned it young. Don't never trust  nobody. Be ready for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Scully, both daring him to contradict, and  desperately pleading for assurance that this is not so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father beat that into me. That's  why I'm alive today. (his pleading,  forbidding look  intensifies)

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY FROM SWEDE'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: Scully means well but all this is far beyond him; besides he is wholly wrapped up in the immediate situation. He is studying the Swede very carefully, in deep concern and  puzzlement. After a moment he puts his lamp on the table sits on the edge of the bed, CAMERA SWINGING to keep him  centered. MEDIUM SHOT -- SCULLY R.S. -- SWEDE STANDING L.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ruminatively) By cracky, I never heard of such a  thing in my life. It's a complete  muddle. I can't for the soul of me  think how you ever got this idea  into your head. (a short silence) And did you sure think they were  going to kill you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scans him as if he  wants to see into  his mind. At last,  with a great effort) I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns again to the valise straps, back to Scully. His  whole arm shakes, his elbow wavering like a bit of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (banging impressively  on the footboard of  the bed) Why, man, we're goin' to have a line  of illictric street-cars in this  town next spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stupidly, vacantly) A line of electric street-cars. (he gets busy on the  other strap)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's a new railroad goin' to  be built down from Broken Arm to  here. Not to mention the four churches  and the smashin' big brick  schoolhouse. Then there's the big  factory, too. Why in two years  Rrhahmpr'll be a metropolis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he straightens up  and politely awaits  the termination of  the foregoing lines) Mr. Scully, how much do I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sore; getting up) You don't owe me one red cent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do. (he takes coins from  his pocket and offers  them to Scully, who  snaps his fingers in  disdainful refusal;  their eyes rest on  the open palm between  them, gazing in a  strange fashion)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The open palm, very heavy and alive, tailors' marks and  callouses on it, trembling faintly; three quarters on it. MEDIUM SHOT -- SCULLY R.S. -- SWEDE STANDING L.S. Their eyes lift from the open palm and meet strangely in  silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) I'll not take your money. Not after  what's been goin' on here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of a sudden he begins to look very crafty. The Swede  watches the change in his face with deep uneasiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes to Scully, looking still more uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking still more crafty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, here! (he turns and picks  up the lamp, CAMERA  following, and comes  back close again,  beckoning, guileful) Come with me a minute.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: Recoiling in overwhelming alarm.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: Pressing closer; wheedling, crafty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Come on! I want you to come and  see a pitcher -- just across the  hall -- in my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swede very close, his teeth shaking like a dead man's; PU BACK to bring in Scully very close in almost the posture a Judas about to plant the kiss, eyes slantwise up to the taller man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. There's nuthin' to be afraid  of: Come on. (he starts for the  door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL CAMERA BACK and lead them out through the door, Scul holding his lamp high, the Swede following with the step one hung in chains.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: The lamp is thrust through darkness high upward against t wall of Scully's room, picking up first a sliding swatch ornate wallpaper, then a ridiculous photograph of a littl girl, the figure graceful as an upright sled-stake. She i the hue of lead. She leans against a balustrade or gorgeo decoration. The formidable bang to her hair is prominent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, that's the pitcher of my little  girl that died. Her name was Carrie.  She had the purtiest hair you ever  saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to take Scully close, looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I was that fond of her, she --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scully's eyes to the Swede, SWING CAMERA onto the Swede,  Scully beyond him. He is not looking either at Scully or picture but is keeping keen watch on the gloom at the rea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Look, man! That's the pitcher of my  little girl that died. Her name was  Carrie. (Swede is around,  reluctant, scared,  uninterested. As his  eyes lift toward the  picture, SWING CAMERA  to lose him, and  past Scully, and to  new picture as Scully  continues) And then here's the pitcher of my  eldest boy, Michael... (graduation shot, cap  and gown, a smart,  shrewd, ambitious- looking young Irishman) ...he's a lawyer in Lincoln, an'  doin' well. I gave that boy a grand  eddication an' I'm glad for it now.  He's a fine boy. Look at him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't he bold as blazes, him there  in Lincoln! An honored and respected  gintleman. (turning to the Swede) An honored and respected gintleman. (he smites the Swede  jovially on the back;  the Swede smiles  faintly, lugubriously) Now, there's only one thing more. (he turns from the  wall and the Swede  turns his head back  to CAMERA to look.)

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: He drops to knees, plants his lamp on the carpet, and bur under the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled) I'd keep it under me piller if it  wasn't fer that boy Johnnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Then there's the old woman -- Where  is it now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from under bed) I never put it twice in the same  place. Ah, now, come out with ye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrambling and grunting he backs from under the bed dragg an old coat rolled into a bundle, flecked with lint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've fetched him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts brushing off flecks of lint.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: The Swede, his eye sharpening. Scully brushes off a last little whisk of lint and carefu unrolls the coat, and extracts from its heart a large yel brown whiskey bottle. He holds the bottle against the  lamplight. Reassured that nobody has been at it, he thrus it upward with a generous movement toward the Swede.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: He is about to eagerly clutch this element of strength bu suddenly jerks his hand away and casts a look of horror u Scully. Scully gets to his feet, lamp in one hand, bottle in the  other, and takes a step toward the Swede.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (affectionately) Drink.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY AND SWEDE
dialogues.text: Lighted only by the lamp. A silence. Scully clamps the bo under the lamp-bearing arm, twists out the cork, holds ou both bottle and cork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the Swede laughs wildly. He grabs the bottle, sc it into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: Small, worried, the beginning even of a look of fright.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: In witch-like lamplight: bottle tilted high, lips curling around the opening, throat working and SOUNDS of his  swallowing: his eyes, burning with hatred, fixed upon Scu

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE'S EMPTY CHAIR
dialogues.text: A long astounded silence. The Easterner lights a cigarett

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost reverently) That's the dod-dangdest Swede I ever  see!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) He ain't no Swede.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what is he then? What is he  then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astutely and  deliberately) It's my opinion he's some kind of a  Dutchman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnnie is impressed; the Easterner, interested and amuse by both of them, covers his amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Yes, sir, it's my opinion this feller  is some kind of a Dutchman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sulkily) Well he says he's a Swede anyhow. (to Easterner) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you think makes him  act like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, he's frightened. (he flicks ash in  spittoon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA slowly creeps them into close up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) He's clear frightened out of his  boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in unison) What at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner reflects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again in unison) What at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly turning the  cigarette between  his fingertips,  scrutinising the  coal) Oh, I don't know, but it seems to me  this man has been reading dime novels  about the wild west, and he thinks  he's right out in the middle of it --  the shootin' and stabbin' and all. (he looks to the Cowboy  and then to Johnnie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deeply scandalized) But this ain't Wyoming, ner none o'  them places. This is Nebrasky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sore and eager) Yeah, an' why don't he wait till he  gits out West?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs quietly) It isn't so wild out there even --  not in these days. But he thinks  he's right in the middle of hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is quiet. Johnnie and the Cowboy muse long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a silence) It's awful funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, this is a queer game. I hope  we don't git snowed in... (Easterner glances  toward front window) ...'cause then we'd have to stand  this here man around with us all the  time. That wouldn't be no good. (he wags his head) No sir ree bob tail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish Pop ud throw him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't do that. He ain't done  nuthin'. Not edsackly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. I don't like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You or me neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are alerted by SOUND of loud stomping on the stairs, o.s. Scully's ringing voice ad lib, no words audible; the Swede's laughter. They all look quickly to the stairway d then "vacantly" at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND of door opening o.s.; all look sharply toward it.

dialogues.speaker: SAME POSITION
dialogues.text: Scully, flushed and anecdotal, swings into the room and d toward the table like all three musketeers. The Swede fol laughing bravely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more or less over  his shoulder) An' then he sez, sez, 'Oh', he sez,  'I've got to bring thim along to  hould the jackass,' he sez: 'He don't  like it.' (plenty of haw haw  from Swede and Scully) 'He don't like it', he sez! Wouldn't  that kill yez?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't like it, huh? Haw, haw,!  Durn good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scully is almost up to the stove, Swede close behind; CAM PULLS BACK to shoot past them at the seated men during  Scully's next line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Come now, move up and give us a chance  at the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy and the Easterner obediently sidle their chair to make room. Johnnie, keeping the board on his lap, simp arranges himself in a more indolent attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, git over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty of room without me movin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (roaring) An' you with the warmest spot in the  house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a patronising bully) No, no. Let the boy sit where he  likes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deferentially) All right! All right!

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY AND EASTERNER
dialogues.text: They exchange glances of wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyhow, I don't know as I want to  sit with these people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just suit yourself Mister. We'd be  glad of yer company, but just suit  yourself. Liberty Hall, ye know. (he laughs nervously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a drink of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at once) I'll git it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) Nahh, I'll get it for myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off with the air of an owner toward and into Scu office. CAMERA LIFTING TO FOLLOW, shooting past tops of t heads of the seated men. As soon as he is out of sight Sc and CAMERA lean down quick and close into the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in an intense whisper) Ye know what? Upstairs? I gave him a  little snort o' what's good for yez,  an' he thought I was tryin' to poison  'im!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not lowering his  voice) Say, this makes me sick, why...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finger to lips) Ssh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice scarcely lowered) ...why don't you throw 'im out in  the snow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, he's all right now. It was only  that he was from the East, and he  thought this was a tough place...

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: Looking with admiration toward the Easterner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) ...That's all. He's all right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Cowboy speaks, the CAMERA SWINGS to include the  Easterner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were straight. You were onto  that there Dutchman, dead to rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he may be all right now, but I  don't see it. Other time he was  scared, but now he's too fresh. Ain't  that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Sure looks like it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like to me he's bound to fall  off one side a th' hoss or t'other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner nods quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Why don't you kick him out, Pop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sharp INTAKE OF BREATH from Scully; all look up sharply

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: PULLING BACK with him as he leans down into group, hands knees, thundering at him with passionate solemnity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I keep? What do I keep? What  do I keep? (he slaps one knee  impressively; shouts) I keep a hotel! A hotel, do ye mind?  A guest under my roof has sacred  privileges. He is to be intimidated  by none. Not one word shall he hear  that would prijiduce him in favor of  goin' away. I'll not have it. There's  no place in this here town where  they can say they iver took in a  guest of mine because he was afraid  to stay here. (he wheels intensely  on the Cowboy and  the Easterner -- to  the Cowboy) Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solemnly) Yes, Mr. Scully, I think you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Easterner) Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solemnly) Yes, Mr. Scully, I think you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA tilts upward a little, shooting across the group,  still HOLDING them in the bottom of the shot; after a sec the Swede re-enters from the office and walks toward them his footsteps heavy, his eyes on them. None of them look or around at him. The SOUND of an opening door, o.s.; Scully's eyes toward

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: Past the stove on the dining room door; Scully's daughter leaning through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low, inhibited voice) Papa: supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost under his  breath) Supper, gintlemen. (he gestures them up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all up and filing toward the door; still no eye the Swede who is walking alone toward them.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: His head is against an almost halation-brassy highlight,  through glass, on a broad perforated mechanical-music dis and, when we PULL BACK, a mechanical violin or mandolin:  stentorian NOISE of the nervous plucking of the perforati and the exact driven rasping screech of the violin (playi some potpourri of Waldteufel waltzes or of early honky-to ragtime): also a NOISE of cranking and of tightening spri The Swede's stooped round shining malignantly grinning fa is on level of disc and much like it. His napkin on, his  hair wetted and combed slick but beginning to spike up aw he laughs low, finishes his cranking and listens a moment with burlesque of connoisseur's or Old Maestro's relish,  imitates a would-be-lyrical phrase of the violin with the skreeky humming of a bass humming falsetto and with mock- affected hands mocking those of a violinist and with a lo of mock ecstasy; then smacks his hands together loudly an does a peasant dance step on his way back to his chair, w is almost directly in front of the machine so that the tu disc backs Swede's head throughout this scene like a phon halo. He scrapes back his chair as loudly as he can; sits down, and looks triumphantly and cruelly and with an air great benefaction from man to man, while he shovels down food in the manner of Henry VIII.

dialogues.speaker: THE EASTERNER
dialogues.text: Looking even smaller than he is, eating rather little; en in reserve.

dialogues.speaker: THE COWBOY
dialogues.text: Staring across at the Swede in wide-mouthed amazement,  forgetting to eat.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: His own version of the Easterner, shoulders huddled, eyes plate, trying to pretend to eat as if nothing were happen

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: The Swede is leering happily sidelong at Johnnie, who is  eating quickly and savagely. PULL AROUND to lose Johnnie CREEP INTO FULL CLOSE UP on the Swede, losing the Cowboy the Easterner. The Swede munches and finishes a huge mouthful, drinks fr his tumbler with parodistic extension of thick pinkie, sw his mouth royally with the apron of the napkin which is t under his ears; flicks glances from eye to eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with brutally mock  incredulity) You gentlemen don't like a little  dinner music?

dialogues.speaker: EASTERNER AND COWBOY FROM SWEDE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: They are even more-so what they were, than before.

dialogues.speaker: FLICK ON SCULLY
dialogues.text: He primly and delicately sips from his glass, looking a l like a hurt old lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe it ain't the custom in your  country? (leans toward Scully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA SWINGS to bring in Scully

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Ain't it the custom Mr. Scully? Am I  making a foe pah, like the feller  says?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up;  mumbling) O, yes, yes. It's a custom. Music or  not, it's all the same.
