dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to table at large,  talking with mouth  full most of the  time, CAMERA PULLS  BACK to center him,  Scully flanking on  r., Johnnie and  Cowboy's shoulder on  l.) Now on the other side, go to a high  class restaurant, beer garden, why  they wouldn't call it a nice place  to eat without they have a feller  with a fiddle, pianner, couple a  palm trees on a little platform,  they play you sweet music while you  eat. (bite; gobble) New York City it's the same. Calms  you down. Cheers you up. Settles yer  stummick good. (drink; bite) But here, (chew) seems like you gentlemen don't enjoy  it. (bite) Maybe you just don't like music.  Hehnh? (he giggles low as he  looks around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Takes another big  bite) 'Course in a low-class joint -- a  domp... (Scully winces) ...you can't expect no musicians,  nor no appreciation, neither. Bunch  of ignorant louts is all. Ain't that  right, Mr. Scully?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scully half nods, not speaking or looking; trying to pret to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Yah, just a bonch a louts. (flicks his eyes around) Tough guys. (flicks eyes and  giggles) But this ain't no domp! (giggles) Oh no. (giggles harder) And you ain't no tough guys. (flicks and giggles  harder) Ooohh no! (laughs outright) Are ye Johnnieboy? (he side-swipes Johnnie  with his eating elbow;  Johnnie swipes back  hard; Swede roars  with laughter.) Oh, I beg yer pardon Johnnieboy! I  got to mind my manners I can see  that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vertical over biscuit plate as the Easterner's small, rea hand is all but impaled by the Swede's fork, reaching for biscuit.

dialogues.speaker: EASTERNER
dialogues.text: ANGLE Easterner's reaction, which is to cover up as quick possible.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: He glints expectantly toward the Easterner, bursts into l laughter at his reaction, which he translates as cowardic Up through the SOUND of his hard loud laughter and the ha loud music, comes an enigmatic racket; the chuffing, grow roar, the banshee wail of wind in the chimney. The Swede' laugh bites off like a hatchet through a hen's neck: he i transfixed by the profound fright which unexpected noises cause in some men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Scully) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. The ROAR continues. The Swede's fear increases

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE TABLE PAST SCULLY
dialogues.text: Three grateful, happy faces, nobody eating, eyes all lift to study Swede. CLOSE SHOT -- SWEDE -- SCULLY IN AT R.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that I said!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK a little, equalizing the Swede and Scul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with sardonic relish) Nuthin' to be scared of Mister. Just  the wind. Just the angle of the wind  in the chimney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all resume eating; little glances to the Swede and e other; plenty pleased.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: He listens a moment; the SOUND begins slowly to diminish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly, heavily) Who's scared? (he looks around;  silence) Who says so? (looks around again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA begins to PULL BACK on his bullying glance to thei silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; low hard  giggle begins) Me scared? (giggle) Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA arrests pull-out; Swede is centered, Scully and Jo and the Cowboy's shoulder flanking. The giggle breaks int full malicious laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; finally;  to Johnnie) Butter please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnnie acts as if he didn't even hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; reaching  across Johnnie for  the butter just short  of brutally enough  to require action) Thankk you, son. (he takes a huge hunk  of butter, while  Scully winces, and  loads it onto a split  biscuit. In a  friendly, chatty  manner, to Scully) That's what I like about the hotel  you keep Mister Scully. (chomp, chomp) It ain't got no class but they ain't  nobody can say you're stingy with  the vittles: hah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On "hah?", a mouthful of buttery biscuit wide open in moc friendliness; some of it falls out almost on Scully's pla Swede, in mock embarassment, picks it up as prissily as i it stank and puts it on the edge of his own plate. Scully's daughter enters to clear plates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O parrdon mee. Marrdon me paddum  this pie is occypewed, allow me to  sew you to another sheet, a-har-har- har-har-har, that's a hot one, huh?  How do you like that! This pie is  occypewed. Huh? Oh marrdon me paddum. (the daughter, behind  him, is trying to  get past his elbow:  he makes her have to  lean against him) Miss I ought to say. Mardon me... (he begins to finish  the spoonerism with  silent lips, is taken  by mock surprise,  mock shock, amusement  and delight; Scully  glances up at him  very sharply; to  Scully, pleasantly) She ain't married is she Mister  Scully? (silence; even more  honeyed) How old is your daughter, Mister  Scully? (no answer. -- Daughter  by now has collected  Scully's plate and  vanished down the  line of Cowboy and  Easterner, out of  shot) Mardon me sir I mean sardon me mur;  that ain't a question a gentleman  would ask, is it? Is it Mister Scully? (silence) But it's a fair bet she's older than  Johnnieboy, huh Johnnie? Could pretty  near be Johnnie's mother, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is coming behind him with dessert and now tries to se him; again he forces her to lean, twisting and looking up her with broad mock-admiration; at the moment her face le lowest he winks into her face enormously and clicks his g she shrivels, shoveling his saucer onto the table, and hu away. Scully is damn near ready to take action but the Sw breaks through a comfortable giggle in a voice of deep an kind concern, genuine-seeming enough to counter Scully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor girl. I must of said something  that hurt her feelings. You tell her  how sorry I am Mister Scully if I  don't get a chance to tell her myself,  will you? (no answer) Please sir. They ain't nothing a  gentleman feels so ashamed of as if  he hurts a lady's feelings. Yes, I  tell you, Mister Scully, you're a  mighty lucky man, you got a fine  girl will stay with you she likes  her old Dad so much, when plenty  would just get married and clear  outa this town quick as they got the  chance. Cuts down the overhead, you  don't have to hire no help. Maybe  she gives you her tips, hah? Besides,  you run a hotel that ain't so much  fer class, it makes up fer a lot if  you see a pretty girl around the  place. Hah? Little services she can  do the guests, don't ya know, that  need the woman's touch? Yes, sir, my  opinion is, you're a mighty lucky  man. (but instead of quite  getting out "man"  clearly, he nurses  and relishes along  and delivers a slow  tremendous growling  belch) Now where I come from, a feller that  done that, they'd say it was somethin'  so awful it ain't any use to make  excuses. They'd just say, go on out  an' eat with the pigs. That's in  Europe. But heere: In Americah: Course  in China they tell me, why if you  don't give a nice big belch why your  host his feelings get hurt cause you  ain't got no manners. You give a  belch to prove you like the eats.  Like that. See? But then you ain't  no Chinaman, are you Mister Scully. (the low steady giggle  and the look around) No sir, it takes all kinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around for something else to say; picking his te and talking through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny thing, you fellers don't eat  enough. Look hearty, except a course  our little friend from Philadelphia,  but you don't eat enough. Except  Johnnieboy here. He'll eat you outa  house and home, hah Johnnie? But  Johnnie needs it. Gonna make a man  of him someday hah Johnnieboy? (giggle) If he can eat enough. (giggle) Now me: one thing I can say for  myself, ain't nothing ever hurts my  appetite. I betcha I could eat hearty  off my dead mother's coffin. (the look around) Take tonight. Nobody talking hardly  but me. Nobody but me trying to be  sociable and keep the ball rolling.  Lotsa people that'd put um off their  feed like it done you fellers, but  not me. Like you see it in the papers,  the condemned man ate a hearty  breakfast. Supper I mean. (pleasant laugh) All it takes now to make it perfect  is another little glass of schnapps,  uhh? Settle our chow? Put the stummick  juices to work? Hehnh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to bring Scully into TWO SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost inaudible  muttering) No... think not... moderation...  save it for medicinal purposes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (archly) Oohh, Miss-ter Scully!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scully pulls back his chair and gets up, CAMERA PULLING B to include whole group and table as all pull back and ris with relief. The Swede gets up too; as Scully passes he g him a hell of a whack across the shoulders and steps alon with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, anyhow old boy, that was a  good square meal.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: It looks for a moment as though he might flame out over t matter.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: On their hopeful, expectant eyes. Scully breaks down into a sickly smile and remains silent It is clear from his manner that he is admitting his  responsibility for the Swede's new viewpoint. The Swede towers past Scully and past CAMERA toward the d Scully follows, CAMERA SWINGING with him. As he passes  Johnnie, Johnnie plucks at his sleeve and whispers someth to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in undertone) Why don't you license somebody to  kick you downstairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go along toward and through the door, CAMERA followi CAMERA PICKS UP the Easterner and the Cowboy as they come along the end of the table toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) I thing that Swede had something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything he's got he can keep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he thought Scully was trying to  poison him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go through the door into the main room.

dialogues.speaker: MAIN ROOM
dialogues.text: CAMERA on dining room door, already swinging, catching th as they file in, stiff and silent with antagonism; swing  with them as they pass on the far side of the stove to th crescent of empty chairs; the Swede strides immediately t the best chair, (nearest CAMERA) hand proprietorily on it back; not yet sitting; he wheels on the others as they  straggle into the shot. They are all very tense and still with lounging hostility, intensely silent except when  speaking. The Swede just keeps looking at them until they are all there, all still standing; as if he were a Chairm waiting for members of a meeting to assemble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (domineering) Alll right: where's them cards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Oh, I don't think that's such a very  good idea perhaps...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a wolfish glare) Oh you don't huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (subsiding; meekly) Well, of course it isn't for me to  decide...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (threateningly; to  the Easterner) How about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tightly) It suits me if you gentlemen want to  play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cowboy) Got any objections?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard and taciturn) Suits me Mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like you're out voted Mister  Scully so where's them cards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still trying to be  pleasant) Well now that's friendly of you but  if you gentlemen don't mind I think  I'll just look at me paper; here it  is night already and all day I  haven't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting; to  Johnnie) So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment their glances cross like blades. Then Johnni smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes; I'll play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to include the whole group as he starts for the table. The Swede nods curtly. The Easterner and t Cowboy swap quiet glances. Scully looks uneasy enough alm to intervene; then purses his lips, shrugs faintly, and d out of the group and across shot nearer. CAMERA SWINGS AND HOLDS on him, back-to, turning up the l on the side table for reading.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNIE'S HANDS
dialogues.text: The purring shuffle, swiftly, twice, PULLING OUT AND UP o second shuffle to take Johnnie, back to stove as before, Swede at his left -- i.e. in r.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning from window) It's quit snowin' gintlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back toward reading  table) But a worse wind than ever. Bitter  night. (No comment from anyone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arranging his cards. He is absorbed in the tensions rathe than the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is the only one of them well inside the cards. We see  also his extreme hatred for the Swede, quietly and rather gracefully borne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Swede, after a  silence) Well, it's your bid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes, in a jagged flickering, down to the cards close his chest, then toward each face in turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't hurry me, boy. (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bids rather high: in this game trumps are named only a bidding is finished. HOLD CAMERA on the Swede as the Cowboy raises, Easterner  passes and Johnnie passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Easterner) Couldn't help me out, Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws out his discards and picks up his new cards; lo to the Cowboy, expecting, as we do, the usual WHAM. Move CAMERA into the CIRCULAR SHOT; on the Cowboy as he l down his card, quite gently for him; on the Easterner's m surprised reaction as he plays; on Johnnie playing, his f very quiet and hating; on the Swede as, vindictively, wit scarcely any amusement about it, he WHAMS harder than the Cowboy did all afternoon. His hand moves to rake in the t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) That's my trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a dead voice) So? I played the ace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) That ain't the trump suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his hand still on  the trick) So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Yeah, so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's yours. (he shrugs and tosses  trick to center of  table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA turns on them again, a little more quickly as each plays, picking up their smoldering reactions to the Swede perversity; on the Swede's play he WHAMS again, even hard than before. Again he starts to rake in the trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) That's Johnnie's trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? What's trumps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Clubs, and besides you didn't only  play a trey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My left Pedro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five o' spades yer left Pedro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, five; oh yaah. Five. (shrugs) Okay; it's yours. (he tosses the trick  toward Johnnie) It's only in fun.

dialogues.speaker: THE THREE FROM SWEDE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: Just looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Your play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cowboy wonders for a moment whether to go on; then he pla a card quietly.

dialogues.speaker: THE SWEDE
dialogues.text: Watchful and somber. SOUND of Easterner's and Johnnie's  playing.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: In his chair, flinching at the SOUND of the Swede's WHAM  o.s. Continue card sounds and low voices ad lib o.s. as S loads his pipe; lights it; unfurls and arranges his newsp for reading as the CAMERA creeps very slowly toward him i CLOSE UP; starts reading. Card SOUNDS fade and wind SOUND brought up a little. Easterner's voice comes as vague as through ether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) If you'd held onto that Jack we could  have busted them you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Just play your own hand Mister. I'll  take care of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND of shuffling o.s., then of dealing; the card SOUNDS FADE OUT completely and the wind fades to a dreaming whin as we slowly FADE on Scully, deeply absorbed in his readi his lips moving a little.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Just a little soft in focus, faint card SOUNDS, the wind a little; Scully is dozing; a wind-whicker wakes him with jerk with which we jerk to pure focus. He glances up at t clock on the wall to his left; it is eight-twenty-seven a for those who noticed it before the fade, was then seven- fourteen: Scully registers an aging man's surprise and mi embarrassment at old-age dozing. He clearly reproves hims and determines to wake up thoroughly and stay awake till fit hour. He brushes spilled ash and tobacco crumbs from lapel, polishes his glasses, readjusts them on his nose,  resets himself to read; realizes the lamp is smoking a li gets up fussily and adjusts it properly; business with pa again and really settles down to read, with that peering  look of an old priest; lips moving, half-whispering what is reading; a great rumpling turn of the paper, resettles again, peacefully reading fillers and mumbling to himself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whispering mumble) "Lake Titicaca in Peru is the highest  body of fresh water in the world,  altitude a thousand feet. It's depths  have never yet been plumbed." Niver  yet been plumbed. Fascinatin'. Now  isn't that fascinatin'! (he peers) "Some of the Giant Redwoods in  California were sturdy saplings in  the days of King Solomon (Circa 700  B.C.)". Think o' that! (he clucks his tongue) Sturdy saplings were they! My! (he peers) "The longest railroad tunnel on the  North American Continent is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.; in a terrible  voice) You are cheatin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catch just the beginning of Scully's reaction then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA is well toward the front of the room, height o the eyes of the seated men; Scully MEDIUM in r.s., player LONG, down center-to-left. Scully is half out of his chair at the start of the shot; stands up fast, his paper floating, forgotten, to his fee making the only SOUND in the room. His spectacles fall fr his nose as he gets up but, by a clutch, he saves them in mid-air; the hand grasping them is poised awkwardly near shoulder. From the moment he is on his feet, a solid two  seconds of frozen tableau: the Swede half crouching out o his chair, a huge fist, (not shaking) in Johnnie's face;  Johnnie still seated, looking steadily into the blazing o of his accuser. The Easterner, gripping the arms of his c sits very still and is very pale. After this 2-second paralysis, everybody moves as suddenl and simultaneously as if set off by a starter's gun. John rising to hurl himself on the Swede, stumbles slightly be of his curiously instinctive care for the cards and table The loss of this moment allows time for the arrival of Sc (an old man sprinting) and also allows Cowboy time to giv the Swede a shove which sends him staggering back. They a find tongue together (ad lib variants and fragments of li below) and hoarse shouts of rage, appeal or fear, burst f every throat. The Cowboy pushes and jostles feverishly at Swede; Easterner and Scully cling wildly to Johnnie; but  through the smoky air, above the swaying bodies of the pe compellers, the eyes of the two warriors meet each other glances of challenge which are at once hot and steely. At the same instant everybody moves, the CAMERA ZOOMS TO  CLOSE UP at average shoulder height, arriving just in tim to catch them standing up and straining.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNIE
dialogues.text: Struggling against restraint INTO CLOSE UP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says I cheated! He says --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrilly) I saw him! He did! I saw him! I saw --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop now! Stop I say! Stop now --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit now! Quit! D'ya hear --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to all; unheeded) Wait a moment can't you? Oh, wait a  moment!

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE AND COWBOY
dialogues.text: Voices are simultaneous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) What's the good of a fight --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit it! Quit now! Qui --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did! He did!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voices are again simultaneous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...over a game of cards? Wait a  moment!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it now! Stop it I say! St --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says I cheated! He --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a lower tone, o.s., the Cowboy and Swede repeat their  lines. CENTER CAMERA ON JOHNNIE and advance slowly on him into C UP SHOT as he continues

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...he says I cheated! I won't allow  no man to say I cheated! If he says  I cheated he's a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His lips form whatever most extreme suggestion of obscene profane insult can be permitted by inference, covered and silenced by the Swede's still louder bellowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) He did cheat! I saw him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw him! He did! He did!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA, starting with a shot past the Swede's head, cente on Johnnie MEDIUM CLOSE, makes, fairly fast and accelerat steadily tighter and faster and closer, the circling move by which a tethered heifer winds herself up short around post. The players meanwhile are all simultaneously repeat their lines as heretofore with only very close ad lib  variations: out of the din of their voices only key words ring out sharply. The weave of salients is roughly: Stop n... Wait a mom... Quit now... He says... He did!... What's the good... Fight... As the CAMERA thus ropes them in they all close tighter a tighter against one center as if it were literally a rope around them: they come as close as five people can get. T ROUNDING CAMERA, at shoulder height, SWINGS through an ex CLOSE UP of the Swede past Johnnie's head and then of Joh past the Swede's head practically as if they were waltzin and comes to a stop, very close in, profiling Johnnie's  glaring head at l.s and the Swede's in r.s. Now there are words; only the SOUND of excited breathing, then not even that: a sudden great cessation. It is as if each man has  paused for breath. CAMERA PULLS BACK INTO MEDIUM CLOSE -- THE WHOLE GROUP as hands relax and there is a cautious unstiffening away fro center; even the Swede and Johnnie step back a little way Then Johnnie steps forward, fairly close in to the Swede the CAMERA moves in about a foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (less loudly) What did you say I cheated for? What  did you say I cheated for? I don't  cheat and I won't let no man say I  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you! I saw you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA CREEPS very slowly in: Its motion is that of a ver slowly winding snake. CAMERA CENTERS ON JOHNNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll fight any man what says I  cheat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you won't. Not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah be still can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA CENTERS SCULLY AS HE STEPS between Johnnie and Swe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.; he walks back  into shot) Oh, wait a moment can't you? What's  the good of a fight over a game of  cards? Wait a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short pause: the eyes of all five are visible. Already momentum toward war is in them and is already all but  irresistible. Now a series of quick shots, closer in:

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: (His main meaning: How're the chances?)

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: (His look means: Boy, will he back down on a man that acc him of cheating?)

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNIE
dialogues.text: (His look means: You lying son of a bitch, take that back fight.)

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: (His look means: You know damn well you cheated).

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: (His look means: How about it, son?)

dialogues.speaker: EASTERNER
dialogues.text: (His look means: For God's sake let's not have a fight.)

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNIE
dialogues.text: The others flanking: quick, steady glances at Scully, Cow Easterner. From each face we can see from Johnnie's face  that he gets fuller and fuller confirmation toward fighti Johnnie steps from behind Scully and walks slowly forward He looks very quiet and brave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Did you say I cheated?

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY TO THE SWEDE
dialogues.text: Intense silence.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNIE
dialogues.text: Very gallant and graceful, waiting. SWING CAMERA SLOWLY to lose Johnnie and bring in Swede wh is standing still. A short silence. The Swede looks like a liar sticking wit his lie. Even after he finally decides, he waits a moment when he speaks his monosyllable it is as if he finally ju off a high building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (showing his teeth) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: Johnnie in l.s., the Swede in r.s. For a moment everyone very still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very quietly) Then we must fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (instantly; roaring) Yes, fight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (roaring like a demon) Yes fight! I'll show you what kind  of man I am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS AWAY slowly to include the three noncombatan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'll show you who you want to fight!  Maybe you think I can't fight! Maybe  you think I can't! I'll show you,  you skin, you card-sharp! Yes, you  cheated! You cheated! You cheated!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the last sentence CAMERA also includes Johnnie, who st cool and quiet. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) Well, let's get at it, then, Mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All five stand very still. Then Cowboy, catching Scully's eye, beckons him aside with his chin. The others stay sti as they move apart toward the middle of the room.

dialogues.speaker: PULLING SLOWLY BACK
dialogues.text: He walks slowly, stooping next to Scully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (just above a whisper) What ya goin' to do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA SWINGS to include Scully, the Cowboy watching him  closely. CAMERA LOSES Cowboy by middle of Scully's lines, centerin on Scully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stalwartly) We'll let 'em fight. I can't put up  with it any longer. I've stood this  crazy Swede till I'm sick. We'll let  them fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns out of shot, toward the coats. In his place, MED DISTANCE, we see the Easterner, his eyes on the Cowboy, v closely. SWING AND PULL CAMERA so that the Cowboy is agai in CLOSE UP r.s., Easterner MEDIUM, watching him closely. the Cowboy's earnest face there is deep-country blood-lus He turns from the CAMERA toward the Easterner and the gro and walks through them toward the coatroom, not speaking. he walks and diminishes, the others come into view. The Easterner holds his eye until he is past. Johnnie, ha hooked in his belt, is looking coolly, studyingly, at the Swede. The Swede, hands open and heavy at his sides, shou rounded, a little farther apart from the group than they from each other, is looking calmly, darkly and a little  solemnly, at Johnnie; in a sense he may suggest a chained bear which is about to be baited. It is the Easterner who has especially caught the Cowboy's eye and expression. Hi reaction is that strange, wavering, uncontrollable smile  with which some people, to their astonishment and shame,  react to news of catastrophe. Just before the Cowboy gets out of their range the other two glance toward him. Johnn with a little smile, looks back into the Swede's eyes. Th Swede, looking sweaty, ungainly and bashful, looks at the floor. The Cowboy walks on between them and toward the coat-corr Johnnie is the first to follow him; then the Swede, with curious lethargic doggedness, looking almost sleepy; then the Easterner, as shakily as if it were he who was going fight. In the b.g. Scully is already hunching into his co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACKWARD through the coat-corridor (lighted lamp) past Scully, who is now buttoning up his coat. The  only SOUNDS are breathing, carefully controlled, and the  SOUNDS of clothes and feet. Johnnie comes up to Scully an past him, for his coat; a silent exchange of glances, the son calm, the father calm and proud: Johnnie slips into h coat easily and gracefully. Only he and Scully are comple calm. The Cowboy, with excited hot eyes is putting on his fur cap with shaky hands. Johnnie meets the Swede's eyes  very coolly, almost humorously, as the Swede muscles thro for his coat. In this highly charged atmosphere all of th men try their best not to touch each other, but the Swede in ungainliness, does touch Johnnie as he passes. A cold  little smile from Johnnie; Swede tightens his mouth. As we PULL BACK, and the Easterner works his way in, the  Cowboy catches his eye; the Easterner's glance quickly dr The Swede looks at nobody and nobody looks at the Swede e when they are sure he will not see. The Easterner and the Swede get to their coats at about the same time. The East is very nervous; he has trouble finding the sleeve of his coat but he finally makes it. The Swede wraps a thick kni muffler high around his throat. He is very thick-fingered buttoning his leather coat and, in spite of his efforts t subdue it, we HEAR him begin to breathe heavily. The East watches his clumsiness; he clearly has a sudden impulse t help and he clearly knows that he must not. The Swede put on his foolishly small cap and tries to pull the too-smal flaps down over his ears; the cap would obviously not sta on in a fight; he takes it off, looks at it for a moment, and hangs it back on a hook. Those who are already in their coats start drifting away  from the CAMERA into the main room and out of shot; the S and the Easterner are alone at this last moment. Almost  timidly, the Easterner looks up into the Swede's eyes,  obviously thinking hard about something; perhaps even abo to speak. The Swede walks past without even seeming to se him. The Easterner, with the helpless and fatal look of a piece of foam snapping over the lip of a waterfall, follo him. LONG SHOT -- MAIN ROOM -- FRONT DOOR IN DEEP R.S. The shot is made from the corner opposite the door, inwar end of the room, past the stove, including the side table and lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the door, calling  the stragglers who  are already halfway  up the room) Well, come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With their very differing gaits, they all hurry up a litt Scully opens the door. STORM NOISE. A terrific blast of w makes the lamp struggle at its wick, a puff of black smok springs from the chimneytop as the men hurry out; the sto gets the cold wind next: its voice swells to equal the ro of the storm and there is the frightening crackling and  hammering of hot metal too abruptly chilled; SWING CAMERA DOWN as some of the scarred and bedabbled cards are caugh up from the floor and dashed helplessly against the end w (some, including a face card or two, hang flat against th wall a few inches from the floor) with SOUND of closing d these cards start to fall; before they reach the floor,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outdoor violence as, with lowered heads, the men plunge i the tempest as into a sea.

dialogues.speaker: PAST FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: The CAMERA is medium close to the door, waist-high, shoot past the door toward the station, as they stumble out. FU SOUND of a very strong wind, but more compelling than any other noise, a pure electric or electronic SOUND, without timbre, either so high it is just at the limit of audibil or so high that it is just beyond that limit and works pu on the nervous system (experiment will determine which is better used in this context). There is no falling of snow; the wind is so strong it mak them stagger and stumble; they all bow deep and turn thei backs to the wind as promptly as if they saw God; the win blows great whirls and clouds of flakes, streaming southw with the speed of bullets. Though we have known from insi that a strong wind is blowing, this exceeds all expectati a solid shrieking roar like flame, plus the supersonic sc which is on a high dead level.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little above head-height, leads their floundering along the hotel faзade toward the station, (leeward side of the hotel). As they flounder into a thigh-deep drift we hear shapeless illegible bawling of the Swede,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rough approximation) I haven't got a chance against you  bastards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA DIPS a little toward them into a fairly CLOSE SHOT Scully waits, puts a hand on his shoulder, and projects a ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting: it is just  possible to hear him) What's that you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bawling) I say, I won't stand much show against  this gang. I know you'll all pitch  on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hits him reproachfully  on the arm; yelling) Tut, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violent wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (booming) You're all a gang of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wind obliterates the word. They start again, CAMERA PULLS AHEAD of them all, facing  them; brings in the corner of the hotel and swings swiftl into the lee of the building as the Cowboy and Johnnie tu in. Immediate and striking diminution of NOISE: but SUPER NOISE is not diminished. CAMERA with them, facing the wal they walk a few paces in and stand waiting, fairly close the wall, Johnnie looking toward the corner, the Cowboy t the CAMERA. There is a little light from one first-floor  window (coat corridor); its shade is drawn.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN PAST JOHNNIE AND COWBOY
dialogues.text: An irregular v-shape of heavily encrusted grass amid this great devastation of snow. A long faint rectangle of ligh from the window. SOUND of crackling of feet on grass o.s.; both heads turn sharply.

dialogues.speaker: EASTERNER, SCULLY AND THE SWEDE
dialogues.text: They come around the corner. CAMERA at Cowboy's distance  from the corner but a few feet farther out from the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still bellowing as  they come up) Oh I know what kind of a thing this  is! I know you'll all pitch on me! I  can't lick you all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning on him  'panther fashion'.) You'll not have to whip all of us.  You'll have to whip my son Johnnie.  An' the man what troubles you durin'  that time will have me to dale with!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWING CAMERA to center on Cowboy, Easterner and Johnnie. latter is quiet, noncommittal; a spasm of contempt on the Cowboy's face; the Easterner's teeth are chattering, he i stomping his feet and is as jittery with cold as a jumpin jack.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: His big head pivoting as he looks from one to another  sullenly, still suspicious. Scully takes him by the upper arm and leads him cumbrously, CAMERA SWINGING and PULLING BACK a few feet, away from the wall and into shot with  Johnnie, who steps forward into shot; Scully grabs Johnni upper arm too. The Cowboy comes in close behind Scully; t Easterner close behind the Swede, (in l.s.) the Easterner alone among the men, is still trying to keep himself warm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a voice of iron  authority) All right now. Fight as ye are: ye'll  not strip in this weather. Bare fists  to a finish, no holds, no kneeing,  no kicks, no gouging. Fight to be  ended when ayther man calls quits or  at me own discretion. That  satisfactory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnnie and the Swede glance at Scully briefly and at eac other briefly. The Swede nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suits me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They keep on looking at each other, the Swede very pale a still; Johnnie serene yet ferocious. Both are taking care not to blink but the Swede blinks once; on Johnnie's face noting it, a calm flicker of contempt. Scully plants a hand on each chest and sets them away fro him and apart just out of each other's reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he sets them apart) Now await me signal and abide by me  instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They raise their fists, Johnnie with something of the  suppleness of a good modern boxer of his time; the Swede  bearish and archaic, slightly suggesting early 19th centu boxing prints, pumping his fists just perceptibly. He sta solid as rock, very heavy and dead on his feet but looks  hard to knock off them. The Cowboy, hands on sprung thigh like a shortstop, face tight, eyes brilliant; the Eastern hugging his arms, looking sick, glancing intently from fi to fighter. It is while CAMERA CENTERS on him or during h close up that the storm seems to get its long mellow cry.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: The Cowboy and the Easterner are not in the shot unless i the b.g. Pretty close on the Swede, CAMERA at about shoul height: he is pale, motionless, terrible; SWING to Scully the iron-nerved master-of-ceremony; then to Johnnie, sere yet ferocious, brutish yet heroic; PULL AWAY and CENTER o Scully with the Swede in r. s. and Johnnie in l.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a sharp glance  to each of them) Now! (no manual gesture)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NOTE ON THE FIGHT: This is to be a sensational fight bu not in any traditional melodramatic sense of that. It is  extremely violent but spasmodic, full of unskillfulness, very clumsy -- the clumsiness enhanced by heavy clothing by occasional veerings onto patches of glare-ice. Though violence is of itself shocking, the chief shock or sensat element is getting the shock of two essential amateurs, n fighters, in something close to mortal combat: almost as  disconcerting as if one saw a couple of clergymen trying beat each others' brains out. This can be arrived at thro the ice, heavy clothes, ungainliness and lack of skill. I is also clear that you can kill a man whether you know ho or not. Both soon learn that in such heavy clothing  practically all that's worth trying to hit is the head; t Johnnie, assuming that the Swede is soft in the middle, t pumping them into his belly with hard loud smacks of fist against leather. The fight is not shot in detail or from  either fighter's angle, but as the spectators see it -- n very clearly. SOUNDS of blows and breathings are way up.  Insofar as possible, the best fight would come of ad libb it, barring a few junctures necessary to the story. The two men crash together like bullocks and there is a  perplexity of flying arms. We so exaggerate the SOUND of crash that the audience feels it like a kick in the belly and instead of any sparring or fooling around they instan start socking with all their speed and strength. Both are evidently trying for instant and pulverizing victory; als it is very thoroughly a hatred-fight. They work with this intensity as long as their first wind and strength holds. They veer side to side and back and forth enough in this  first phase that the CAMERA has to waver back and fill a  little, but nothing special -- except that it should not  frame them too carefully or neatly. The spectators, movin slightly when they need to, get into and out of shot ad l As they first crash and sock, a squeezed curse, -- it is  indistinguishable from which fighter. (For 'curse,' try s the first 2/3rds of "God" and "Christ" simultaneously, fr between tight teeth).

dialogues.speaker: THE EASTERNER
dialogues.text: His pent-up breath explodes with a pop of relief from the tension of the preliminaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., a sort of Texas  yowl)

dialogues.speaker: THE COWBOY
dialogues.text: In mid-yowl and in mid-air; he lands on his feet again an hands on knees, looks intently.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: Immovable as from supreme amazement and fear at the fury the fight which he himself had permitted and arranged. SOUNDS of fight are strong o.s. over all these shots.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE AND JOHNNIE
dialogues.text: and as suggested above; till they draw away to get their  wind; and they now come at it more cautiously. After some sparring and some wild misses, the Swede becomes impatien and tries to be a bulldozer; by his sudden drive toward t CAMERA, the fighters all but knock it over, and the CAMER has to "step" quickly aside, mindful for a moment only of its footing, as the fighters pass in a blur.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ANGLE
dialogues.text: The fighters are past the CAMERA which now, reversed on f position, shoots away from the hotel wall; the three  spectators come slowly into the shot, flanking and back-t The drive continues though Johnnie is now giving near as  good as he gets; but retreating a little and wheeling.  Wheeling, they almost simultaneously hit glare-ice. Johnn surer-footed, keeps his feet, the Swede falls heavily  backward, to some extent saving himself with one hand. Sc comes up to them fast, the CAMERA nearly as fast; he  needlessly stays Johnnie with one hand for Johnnie is sta a little too close over the Swede.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with what breath he  has, but not jumping  him) Get up. Get up and fight. Get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scully has lifted his other hand as if for a count but th Swede grunts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't lay there all night then you  yellow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up Johnnie it was no true fall.  The man's got a right to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But already the Swede lumbers to his feet, dukes ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staying the Swede) Git back off the ice both o' yez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads them in toward the hotel, the CAMERA PULLING BAC with them, and steps back to the edge of shot, skidding a little himself. A second's hesitation, the Swede seeming a little slow an stunned, then Johnnie drives in on him with terrible  intensity, the Swede covering up clumsily, Johnnie workin mainly on the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking much more excited than before. Johnnie is delivering hard, fast blows against the Swede' hands which are trying to guard his head, and is then  hammering clublike wrists on the bowed nape of the Swede' neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling and springing  forward into the  shot) Go it Johnnie! Go it! Kill him! Kill  him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scully comes into shot quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barring him) Kape back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By his glance the Cowboy can see that this man is Johnnie father. Scully's manner in this must be something to resp

dialogues.speaker: THE FIGHTERS
dialogues.text: Johnnie is still hammering but has grown wholly careless his guard. Suddenly the Swede uncorks a sonofabitch to th belly which doubles Johnnie, and misses a lulu to the hea as Johnnie ducks and backs off, getting his guard up; the the Swede lands a wild one to the head which Johnnie  sufficiently covers and glances off that they are now aga somewhere near even. The Swede rushes it, taking as much he gives, which is plenty.

dialogues.speaker: PAST THE EASTERNER
dialogues.text: A monotony of unchangeable fighting which is an abominati Both horribly skid but stay on their feet. As soon he has his balance, the Swede closes and pours it on; Johnnie re equality; they lurch so near the Easterner that he has to scramble hastily backward and we HEAR them breathe like m on the rack.

dialogues.speaker: THE EASTERNER
dialogues.text: His sickened face, wishing it would end, no matter how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., bellowing) Kill him Johnnie! Kill him! Kill  him!

dialogues.speaker: THE COWBOY
dialogues.text: By the middle of the foregoing line. His face is contorte like one of those agony masks in museums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (icily, to Cowboy) Keep still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy leans into the shot, puzzled and offended, loo at Scully and Scully at him. SOUND o.s., of a sudden loud grunt, incomplete, cut short their eyes toward the fight.

dialogues.speaker: FROM ANGLE OF SCULLY AND COWBOY
dialogues.text: Johnnie's body swings away from the Swede and falls with  sickening heaviness. The Swede, with a kind of wild anima snarl, (roughly, Arghrgh) is obviously about to swing him headlong on Johnnie.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS JOHNNIE
dialogues.text: SOUND o.s., of running as the Swede hovers. The Cowboy ru into MEDIUM CLOSEUP and interposes an arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Swede) No you don't! Wait a second!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scully hurries into the shot, nearer us, standing but lea over his son like a mother to a crib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tenderly) Johnnie! Johnnie, me boy! Johnnie!  Can you go on with it? (he is looking  anxiously down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring CAMERA down into a CLOSE SHOT, almost upside down f our angle, of Johnnie's bloody, pulpy face. Scully squats and his head returns into the shot, close a Johnnie's. A moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in his ordinary voice) Yes, I... it... yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scully's arm under his nape and then his shoulders, tende nearest to us; clumsy, humiliated and piteous getting-up helping-up, mostly back-to the CAMERA. CAMERA LIFTING to  level of the standing men, brings in the Cowboy and the S in b.g.,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still rumbling) You wait a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner steps into the shot at r.s., a hesitant han toward Scully's sleeve. As Johnnie gets fully to his feet, the CAMERA PULLS AROUN his left shoulder; Scully still has an arm across his bac the Easterner comes closer into the shot on the far side Scully. But the moment he gets his footing, Johnnie moves throw off his father's arm and veers toward the Swede, fi readying, but obviously weak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a bit now till you get your  wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) You wait a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a hesitant hand at  Scully's sleeve, a  low sick voice,  pleading) Oh, this is enough! This is enough!  Let it go as it stands. This is  enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this speech, the CAMERA has PULLED AROUND so that  Scully is in full face CLOSE UP, the Easterner a pinched  profile at the side. Scully acts exactly as if he hadn't  heard except that his face gets hard as iron. We hear the SOUND of Johnnie's wavy breathing but his face is not in shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) Bill.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND HIM
dialogues.text: The Cowboy says nothing; an enquiring look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still more iron in  his voice) Git out o' the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND o.s. the Cowboy's backward step.

dialogues.speaker: FULL FACE, FULL LENGTH
dialogues.text: Cowboy one more step back and at side. The Swede, fists c up, starts slowly, stonily forward.

dialogues.speaker: FULL FACE, FULL LENGTH
dialogues.text: Scully stepping out of shot toward the CAMERA. Johnnie is more cautious and much less arrogant than before: still h stupid from weakness. After Johnnie's advance is started, the CAMERA PULLS OUT, facing the wall and opposite the referee's position (the  three spectators pull close into a bunch), HOLDING Johnni in the shot in r.s., the Swede coming in from the left. T Swede aims a lightning blow that carries with it his enti weight. Johnnie, despite his daze, miraculously dodges. H (Swede's) fist sends the overbalanced Swede sprawling (fa side of Johnnie, almost fouling up his feet) a brutally h fall to shoulder and a hog-like grunt; a burst of cheerin from the three onlookers. The Swede cuts it short by scuf agilely to his feet and coming in berserk abandon at his  foe. Another blinding perplexity of flying arms and again not from any particular blow we can distinguish, Johnnie  swings away and falls, even as a bundle might fall from a roof. The Swede staggers out of l.s. as the three others, and the CAMERA, hurry to Johnnie. The CAMERA fetches up opposite Scully as he stoops, shoot from a little above him, down on his face and on Johnnie. Johnnie is lying on his face, the bloody backs of his unf hands, are near his head, rather like a sleeping baby's, the snow. LOWER CAMERA CLOSER on to him, to height of Scu stooped head; TILT TO CLOSE UP of Scully's heartbroken fa

dialogues.speaker: AT HEAD-HEIGHT
dialogues.text: They are standing but leaning. The Cowboy is looking down past Scully, at Johnnie; so is the Easterner at first; th he looks out l.s. toward the Swede.

dialogues.speaker: THE SWEDE
dialogues.text: He is leaning heavily against a little wind-waved tree,  breathing like an engine, while his savage and flame-lit  eyes roam from face to face... a mysterious and lonely fi waiting... a splendor of isolation in his situation.

dialogues.speaker: EASTERNER
dialogues.text: His sad but awed reaction, still looking toward the Swede his eyes turn to Johnnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost vertical over Johnnie as Scully and the Cowboy (wh has come opposite Scully) gently turn him onto his back,  their arms sustaining his head and chairing his shoulders little off the ground. The faces of Scully and the Cowboy are hardly visible at this angle, and are drastically  foreshortened, so that the upper face of each looks like  some kind of grotesque mourning mask. Johnnie's face, cra up toward nearly vertical CAMERA, is also somewhat  foreshortened but much less so. It is ghastily beaten,  bloodied, cut and swollen, eyes shut, neck limp; head far backward and point of chin highest at start of shot, then through normal view into aforementioned foreshortening; t again to normal view. Blood has matted his dark hair to h forehead and over one eye. Ice and snow are on his face l a broken mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you any good yet, Johnnie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing from Johnnie. With his free right hand, tenderly as a woman, Scully smo back the clotted hair from the smeared, smooth, very youn looking forehead, and wipes away the ice and snow. Johnnie gasps and opens his eyes languidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) No... I ain't... any good... any...  more. (he begins to cry) He was too... too... too heavy for  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Scully gets to his feet, PULL CAMERA up and back to ce on him in MEDIUM CLOSE UP from the Swede's angle. Cowboy Johnnie low in r.s., the Easterner still closer in l.s.,  watching Scully. Scully straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evenly) Stranger, it's all up with our side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner's eyes to the Swede, quickly back to Scully

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly tragic) Johnnie is whipped.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: Without replying, he leaves his tree, walks toward and pa them, CAMERA keeping him centered, the Easterner's eyes  following him, Scully not moving or looking at anything:  CAMERA SWINGS with the Swede (who passes between it and t hotel wall) and HOLDS ON HIM as he passes out of the lee the house to where the wind hits him like a Mack truck an tears at his clothes; he disappears bowed-over deeply, ba to the storm.

dialogues.speaker: EASTERNER
dialogues.text: His eyes return from the Swede, absently and indifferentl toward Johnnie. He is chiefly aware that he is freezing.  Bring up SOUND of storm strongly.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: His crumpled, leaning face, from Johnnie's angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Tsah-right Johnnie. Tsah-right kid.  We'll fix him. We'll sure fix him.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: His eyes are still on the Swede's face but are out of foc He has not moved since his surrender. His face has change only in looking still older, more stern, more sad, more  tragic. He lowers his eyes and stoops toward Johnnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy has him half-sitting; Cowboy's profile r.s.,  Scully's comes into shot at left; Johnnie's eyes are avoi everything. Scully puts out a hand toward an instinctive  caress and quickly withdraws it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnnie, can you walk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I hurt... hurt him any?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you walk, boy! Can you walk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with robust impatience) I asked you if I hurt him any!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, Johnnie, he's hurt a good  deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cowboy) Let's get him up, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS SLOWLY BACK and up with them: They get well under him and lift; he winces and gasps in  spite of himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aisy does it. That's the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's 'at now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnnie savagely shakes off their hands, totters toward t CAMERA, quickly gets his bearings and turns, walks betwee them and leads them, back-to the CAMERA, toward the corne of the hotel. Scully and the Cowboy fall in, timidly guar like, just behind each shoulder; the Easterner, who has n moved since the Swede left, falls in behind them.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: From just above and ahead of them as they flounder along  past the faзade of the hotel toward the door. Storm SOUND up. The Swede's staggering, shapeless tracks are still conspi in the difficult snow; Johnnie, in the lead, avoids makin use of them. After a few paces he flounders badly in the  drift near the door: the Cowboy and Scully, flanking him, are alert but still shy to touch him. They are all practi blinded by the blowing snow. After another couple of step Johnnie is about to fall: the Cowboy comes swiftly to him obviously shouting something the screaming wind tears awa from us; Johnnie fights him off furiously and lunges ahea CAMERA stooping swiftly as he falls: the Cowboy swiftly t him; Scully's heartsick face is disclosed as the Cowboy  stoops, and Easterner's frozen face behind him as Scully  leans; the CAMERA on down to the Cowboy and Johnnie as th Cowboy picks him up as if he were a child and staggers wi him up the drifted steps, Johnnie protesting violently, S hurrying ahead to get the door open.

dialogues.speaker: MAIN ROOM
dialogues.text: From same position of last interior shot, from deepest in corner. For perhaps a half-second, SOUND of ferocious  crackling of the stove and the wrestling trouble inside t lamp in l.s., then the door closes; we hear the SOUND of  falling cards; the lamp rights itself and burns steadily. The Cowboy, painfully embarrassed, is just setting Johnni on his feet; the Easterner has just got inside; Scully is shutting the door. The Cowboy is slow, embarrassed, caref not to walk ahead of Johnnie; Johnnie, rubber-legged and  intensely humiliated, wobbles toward the stove; Scully is his shoulder, taking great care not to touch him or say  anything; the Easterner, the last in, walks as fast as he can past them and up to the stove -- CAMERA ADJUSTING to  center on him -- almost as if he would embrace the stove: is desperately cold and his face looks like ice. We look  past the stove at his face and past that as the CAMERA DO into position where all the chairs will be visible, MEDIU CLOSE. As the others come up, the Easterner quits hogging the stove, moves aside to l.s. chair nearest the wall; Jo sinks into a chair and, folding his arms on his knees, bu his face in them.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: Standing, Scully warms one foot and then the other at the rim of the stove; he shakes his head quietly, looking dow at the hot shoe, making tst-tst-tst with his tongue. SWING CAMERA to the Cowboy, also standing; removing his c with a dazed, rueful air, running one hand through his to locks. SOUND o.s., of the floor creaking and a heavy step he glances toward the ceiling sadly and grimly.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: SOUND of another creak or step. He doesn't look up; his h bows a little.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: On the stove, and beyond it, the dining room door. CAMERA standing height shooting downwards across Johnnie's bowed head (he is back-to us); the Easterner's subtle, melancho profile; the slack hands and bodies, not the heads, of th two standing men. o.s. the SOUND of another creak or foot minimal reaction from the men; then a sudden bursting SOU the noise of a door flung open, (we can see a little of t and of those who enter, past the stove in b.g.): the East listlessly raises his eyes as the CAMERA lifts swiftly pa the bovine head of the Cowboy and the resigned, caught-wi pants-down head of Scully, to catch the wife and daughter swarming in, oh-ohing and ad libbing brogue lamentations. Mrs. Scully shoulders swiftly past the men toward Johnnie CAMERA closes onto her in CLOSE UP, at her speed, above  Johnnie. She is a wiry, fierce, worn-out woman of 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crossing to him) Did he hurt ye child did he hurt ye  so bad? (she squats in front  of him) Lookit me Johnnie let me see yez. (Under this Johnnie,  from his first hearing  of them, has been  shrinking into himself  and now mutters across  her line)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) Cut it out Ma... (a couple of half- whispered words,  covered by loud talk  from her...) ...sake cut it out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she is tugging at his wrists and putting a hand under his forehead to lift his face while he still groans, head muffled in hands,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please! Please! Quit it! Le' me be!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he knows there's no use and she gets his face up (awa from us) and gives a close quick look and then a low keen wail as tears spring out of her and she turns loose of hi stubborn humiliated head to bring her hands incompletely  toward the primordial gesture of tearing her hair at the  temples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands distrait in  the uncompleted  gesture: a wailing  sob) Ohh, me boy! Me little boy! And him  sitchy charmer! Lookit 'im Katy!  Jist lookit that! Ohh ain't it  dreadful, did you ever see sitch a  starin' horror!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With "and him sitchy charmer," CAMERA PULLS BACK and up a little; through the rest of her lines and, the CAMERA, fr the same position, does quick flicking shots like glances the eye, centering reactions of one or another of the men turn and of the daughter -- shots A, B, C, et seq. The  daughter meanwhile is horning in ad lib with "Ohh," and " and "Johnnie dear," "ain't it just awful," "it's a sinful shame," etc., and by a violence of gesture and voice, Mrs Scully drags CAMERA (by quick cut and a shade belated) ba to MEDIUM CLOSE UP of herself past Johnnie's bowed head.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SCULLY
dialogues.text: As she flings herself on her knees before Johnnie, catche his face between her hands, already talking loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a mixture to her  son and the room at  large) Crazy ye are, jist outa yer mind,  an' him a man twice his age an' size,  the great bullyin' murderer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (across her lines, in  rage, humiliation  and disgust) Get away, cut it out, quit it I tell  ya, I ain't hurt bad, I'm all right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning weakly into  shot, aghast with  disgust and sympathy  for Johnnie; in a  weak voice) Molly! (she neither hears  nor sees him) Molly! Please! Molly! Hush now! Molly!  Not here. Molly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Scully does a slow take on him when she finally hear him, cuts off her former lines and whips her head at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with cold fury) Shut up an' keep outa this, you!  Haven't ya done enough, standin' by  while a man half kills my baby boy? (her eyes rake all of  them) Crazy men! Bloodthirsty brutes! (her daughter echoes  her less noisily, ad  lib)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Scully starts bustling up from her knees, CAMERA RIS with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Poor darlin'! Crazy boy, brawlin'  young fool, now jist come with mother,  gently darlin', come darlin', kin ye  walk, son? Come on, let's bathe the  poor blood off an' fix 'im up comfy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnnie meanwhile is still protesting ad lib and is tryin at least to walk alone, as he had with the men, but not a chance; they wholly disregard his gestures of pride, his  efforts to shake them off. With ad libs of "Silly boy," a such, they cling to him like limpets, helping him out pas the stove and thence toward the dining room door. CAMERA meanwhile, SLOWLY TRACKS crabwise, parallel with t wall opposite the coatroom, so that until they get past t stove they are in a kind of Recessional from the CAMERA. They reach the far side of the stove from the CAMERA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straightening;  reproachfully) Shame be upon you, Patrick Scully!  Yer own son, too! Shame be upon you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad lib) Shame, shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scully has huddled meekly out of their path but now comes close to the stove as if he needed the warmth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently, almost  inaudibly, meeting  no eyes) There, now! Be quiet now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shame, I say. Shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn toward the door on the far side of the stove; t CAMERA continues its crabwise glide and stops when stove  centers and blanks out screen, but SWINGS to HOLD them as they half-carry Johnnie back through the dining room door side and back-to the CAMERA; the door closes.

dialogues.speaker: THE THREE MEN
dialogues.text: Over the SOUND of the closing door cut to a new angle, fr the same position, MEDIUM CLOSE of the survivors. The  Easterner, l.s., is in near profile; a crescent of empty  chairs; the Cowboy is standing behind between two chairs; Scully is all but hidden by the stove. Scully walks slowl into the shot, sits down slowly and sadly in the chair ne Johnnie's (next the Easterner, it stays empty); hangs his hands between his knees. His head is bowed; he wags it sl sighs very deeply; head still. The Cowboy, deeply sad and embarrassed, walks slowly arou a farther chair and sits, facing the CAMERA, staring at t stove. The Easterner just looks at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a long pause) Tst-tst-tst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy exhales a deep damp breath through o-ed lips. The Easterner's hand is on his knee, flat and limp except for the forefinger, which he slowly raises and brings dow repeatedly. The Cowboy gets his sack and papers part way out, puts th back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tst-tst-tst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND o.s. of the creaking board in the Swede's room. Fro Scully, a short sharp intake of breath, no raising of the eyes. The Cowboy's eyes don't raise but they harden. He  glances with shy calculation at Scully and at the Eastern and again at Scully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully) I'd like to fight this here Swede  myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner's hand goes still, forefinger up in the air no change in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tempted for a moment,  then, wagging his  head sadly) No, that wouldn't do. It wouldn't be  right. It wouldn't be right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knowing why but making  him say it) Well why wouldn't it I don't see no  harm in it. (he looks to Easterner  whose eyes do not  change)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner's finger is lifted a little higher; motionl again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with mournful heroism) No, it wouldn't be right. It was  Johnnie's fight, and now we musn't  whip the man just because he whipped  Johnnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner's finger relaxes and stays flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's true enough, but (hopefully) he better not get fresh with me,  because I couldn't stand no more of  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (commandingly) Ye'll not say a word to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under Scully's line, the SOUND of the Swede's heavy tread the stairs. Hearing it, Scully makes his last couple of w all but inaudible. None of them look up or register heari but all go very still. The Swede enters "theatrically," h cap on, sweeps the stairway door shut with a bang, and  swaggers to the middle of the room. He is dressed to go a carries his valise in his hand. He has washed his face bu even from here we can see that it is bleeding again in tw or three places. Nobody looks at him, or even looks up. A sit side or back to him, facing the CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud and insolent,  to Scully) Well, I spose you'll tell me now how  much I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no move or look;  stolidly) You don't owe me nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning slowly to  look at Swede) Stranger, I don't see how you come  to be so gay around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting across the  last words, a hand  forth almost in  Cowboy's face, palm  out, fingers straight  up) Stop! Bill, you shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spitting carelessly  into the cuspidor) I didn't say a word, did I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Swede has been watching this, his body tightening lik fist, but quite unfrightened; as he sees there will be no fight, a sour spasm of smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting Cowboy) Mr. Scully, how much do I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imperturbably; as  before) You don't owe me nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh! I guess you're right. I guess  if it was any way at all, you'd owe  me somethin'. That's what I guess. (he pivots fast and  rigidly and takes  two paces toward the  Cowboy; then, leaning  forward, stiff-legged  from his heels, and  mimicking even the  Cowboy's agony-mask,  screams) Kill 'im! Kill 'im! Kill 'im! (he guffaws  victoriously) Kill 'im!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is convulsed with ironical laughter. He watches them w great interest and delight all the time he laughs. He bit it off sudden and cold. There is an arrogant and expectan silence. But the three men are immovable and silent. As throughout this act of the Swede's, they stare with glassy eyes at t stove. They hold it while he waits for trouble, and while walks leisurely to the front door and, with one last deri glance at the still group, passes into the storm. After the door closes (omit all former STORM EFFECTS exce a moment's howl of wind while the door is open) hold a fe seconds of absolute stillness. Then the Cowboy and Scully jump up and begin to tramp around. The Easterner stays ve still in his chair, hardly, if at all, even looking at th but listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whipping from his  chair; fist hard  into palm) Unh! Byg! Golly!

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ANGLE
dialogues.text: He circles behind his chair; he is finishing the above li the first words of Scully lines, o.s., come over this sho Cowboy's eyes to him.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: His fists are shaking with great intensity near his templ he is working his way out between the chairs and toward t Cowboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but that was a hard minute! That  was a hard minute! Him there leerin'  an' scoffin'! (he is pretty CLOSE  now, WHEEL CAMERA  for TWO SHOT, still  favoring Scully) One bang at his nose was worth forty  dollars to me that minute! How did  you stand it, Bill!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy and Scully are equal in the shot now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a quivering voice) How did I stand it? How did I stand  it? OH! (a violent fist through  the air)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK a little, follows Scully. Scully begins paddling back and forth in front of the Cowboy (who stand sort of treading water, making hard little shadow-boxing  jabs); Scully's hands are close together; his shoulders a hunched, he is rapidly hammering fist into palm and waili in deep brogue:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oi'd loike to take that Swede and  hould him down on a shtone flure and  bate 'im to a jelly wid a shtick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (up to him and almost  groaning in sympathy) I'd like to git 'im by the neck and  h-ha-aaammer 'im... (speechless, a hand  down on a chairback  with a SOUND like a  pistol shot) ...hammer that there Dutchman till  he couldn't tell himself from a dead  coyote!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toward the end of the Cowboy's lines, CAMERA favors Scull reaction.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: Eyes to the Cowboy leaning into upper l.s., Scully is alm crying with the lust of this kind of self-abuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd bate 'im until he...

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: Past Scully's round little head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tries to speak; unable)

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: He looks grateful, even loving -- and as if he could hard wait, and as if he wants to prompt him like a stutterer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he looks loving too) I'd show him some things...

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY
dialogues.text: Satisfied, nodding very rapidly but curtly; almost the  masculine equivalent of an old-maid gossip's 'yes-yes-yes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faces contorted, a kind of gloating; as if embracing in  operatic duet, they look almost straight into the lens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost in unison: a  yearning, fanatic  cry) Oh-o-OH! If we only could...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other with breathless and terrible year and again speak almost in unison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YES!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YISS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA SWINGS to lose them, bringing in their inane  shadows on the wall opposite the lamp, chasing each other circles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) An' then I'd... (a sock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Yis, an' I'd... (more socking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Yeah, an I'd... (a terrific blow on  the air; four hard  fast jabs, a gigantic  uppercut, hard  breathing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.; a fierce grunt  of hatred and effort;  he kicks something  which is prostrate)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) A-aaahhh! (he jumps up and down  on it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Oh-o-OH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Oh-o-OH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over Scully's grunting and kicking

dialogues.speaker: THE EASTERNER
dialogues.text: He is staring at the stove, hands slack on his knees; he listening keenly. As contempt and self-contempt increase his face beyond silence, CREEP CAMERA INTO CLOSE UP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet but piercing) Oh, stop it!

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY AND COWBOY
dialogues.text: They are as arrested by his words as in a stopshot. They  look toward him, more surprised than offended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that, pardner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at same time) Eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly contemptuous) I said, stop it. (he gets up and walks  toward CAMERA and  out of shot toward  the front of the  room. Over his next  line, CAMERA SWINGS  across Cowboy and  Scully, watching  him, astonished;  loses them and again  picks up Easterner  as he nears the  stairway door.) Surely there's some limit to  childishness and cowardice and shame!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) What's eatin' you, Mister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner pauses abruptly at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all. I'm going to find that  Swede and try to make up for what  we've done to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes through the door and starts upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY AND COWBOY
dialogues.text: Slowly, dumbfounded, they turn and look at each other. o. SOUND the Easterner's footsteps and, just audible, a trai whistle.

dialogues.speaker: EXT., (NITE)
dialogues.text: Shooting down the narrow boardwalk from the corner of tow (edge of a building in r.s. toward the hotel and station. Minimal lighting. Same SOUND of shrieking wind and blowin snow as before; same SOUND of storm and high, timbreless  scream at the edge of audibility. The line of the boardwa is marked by a little line of naked, gasping trees. In th deep distance, when blowing snow allows, we see the small single, stinging light of the station. The Swede is about halfway between the hotel and the edge town, coming toward us floundering, struggling into the e of the wind, with terrifying spirit and energy -- carryin his big valise and now and then clutching his cap almost  like Harry Langdon. Within a few seconds (see note below method) he comes a full hundred yards. CAMERA shoots him shoulder height, a little upward toward his face. As he g nearer an ordinary CLOSE UP the CAMERA PULLS BACK. For a  moment he just wags his head a little, fast, almost  paretically, looking all around; growing in his face is a hunger for enormity, violence, bragging, love, glory,  something, anything so long as it is huge enough to meet half-way. Suddenly he opens his mouth and yells at the to of his lungs -- then stands, like an idling locomotive,  breathing quiet and fast through clenched teeth. Then his hands begin to move; fists hitting the air. Becoming awar of the suitcase, heavy in his right hand, he mingles grin and weeping and moaning and hits it as hard as he can wit his left fist, and drops it and kicks it twice, three tim as hard as he can. It isn't enough for his desperation an joy; again he scans the darkness; and suddenly, with his  right fist, he hits himself as hard as he able on the joi of the jaw. He reels a little with the blow and whispers  something, and stoops and picks up his valise (CAMERA adj to these violences). As he straightens and starts down th street into the middle of the town, he is smiling with a  strange peacefulness and hope and sweetness -- a tired Pi on the homestretch to Paradise. The CAMERA PANS as he passes closer, and centers on him a he plods down the middle of the snow-foundered, lightless street. (A NOTE ON THIS SHOT): It is to be heightened above reali during the Swede's advance up the boardwalk. When he is s in the deepest distance, we use only every third frame; t every second; then cut every third frame; then every four meanwhile slurring the CAMERA speed a little, fewer frame per second, so that his speed of approach is at all time  superhuman and grotesque, but becomes smoother as he  approaches. By the time his features become distinct no f are skipped but the motion, though regular, is fast and d rather than silky; it is at this time and pace that the t is run through. As he comes into full close up, shade bac to normal speed, omitting no frames. The SOUND runs smoot not clipped; it is not recorded on the spot.

dialogues.speaker: MAIN ROOM
dialogues.text: The staircase door; o.s. the SOUND of the fast train quic dies. The Easterner comes through the door with his trave bag, ready to go. His eyes meet Scully's o.s., and he pau He is quiet and grave.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY AND SCULLY
dialogues.text: They stand waiting for him in the middle of the room and  looking at him with a kind of mystified grimness.
