dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet and reasonable) Now Mr. Blanc, what's all this about?

dialogues.speaker: THE EASTERNER
dialogues.text: He walks toward them, extending his hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Easterner walks into the shot, offering Scully coi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Here's what I owe you Mr. Scully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not accepting) What's your complaint? I thought we  was friends here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Take it. There's no time to  waste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scully makes no move to accept the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) You fer that Dutchman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, what is this about the Swede?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brief pause: the Easterner's feeling conquers his avers against going into it. They watch him judicially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) We've done him a great wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astounded) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong! We couldn't treat him fairer --  we never touched a hair of his head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet but feeling it  strongly) Ah you don't know the meaning of  fairness. Either of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move nearer him; he stands his ground. CAMERA SLOWLY CREEPS CLOSER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you look here, Mister...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Solemn and quiet;  slowly tapping  Easterner's chest  with his forefinger) See here, Sir: guest or no guest,  nobody can tell Patrick Scully he  ain't a fair man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose I prove it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try, just. Fair enough. But Mister:  ye better make it shtick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That goes for me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sets down his bag as the CAMERA stops advancing: A CLO THREE SHOT, favoring the Easterner. He looks coldly from to the other as he talks. They watch him judicially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the Swede said Johnnie was  cheating, and Johnnie called him a  liar, it was one man's word against  another. Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They nod, with a look, "of course."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was all we had to go on to  prevent a fight. Correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. (very quiet and cold) Did it occur to either of you that  the Swede might be telling the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (together; vaguely) Truth?

dialogues.speaker: EASTERNER
dialogues.text: He is watching them mercilessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (icy; just audible) Mm-hm. That's the word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gaping, incredulous,  innocent) HIM?

dialogues.speaker: EASTERNER
dialogues.text: He watches them a moment very tensely, then abrupty relax

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing it away) Thank you, gentlemen: there's your  proof. (again trying to pay) Now please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA circles, favoring each man as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intensely) Are you accusin' Johnnie of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet, cold) I'm accusing nobody. I'm proving you  don't know the a-b-c-'s of fairness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that Dutchman, he's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (biting the words out) Stick to the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he ever did tell the truth -- an'  that I beg leave to doubt -- it'd be  the first time in his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would make it a lie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good as a lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scully nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Splendid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA, shooting past the Easterner, favoring the Cowboy, stops circling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, that bird, if he did tell the  truth, I wouldn't keer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to both) You've proved my point several times  over; don't strain yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes glide quietly from man to man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause. They are cornered; half-comprehending, deeply  resentful. They are in some degree trying to face it.

dialogues.speaker: EASTERNER
dialogues.text: In deep stillness he watches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The effort to face it weakens; they glance toward him alm reproachfully and look quickly down; they glance toward e other but their eyes don't meet. Each does his equivalent a shrug.

dialogues.speaker: THE EASTERNER
dialogues.text: He looks at them in silence a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) That's right; shrug it off; it's a  small matter. It's why wars are  fought; why a great nation can fall  apart like rotten meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., booming) Yeah? Well what're you...

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: SWING CAMERA to bring in Scully, reacting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...talkin' so high and mighty about,  I want to know! You was there too,  but I didn't notice you sayin'  nuthin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot now favors Scully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eager, vindictive) Now how about, yes how about that!  Tarred with the same brush, ain't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look to him in bitter triumph.

dialogues.speaker: EASTERNER
dialogues.text: A pause as he returns their gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with calm self- loathing) Oh no. A blacker brush. (still quieter) You see: I knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are held in a strange, prescient pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very quietly) Yes: Johnnie was cheating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blankly) Johnnie...

dialogues.speaker: EASTERNER
dialogues.text: He nods, watching them closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence. We can almost see their wheels go round. Final relief and pleasure dawn in the Cowboy's face. As he star to speak he makes a foolish, rather pathetically helpless gesture, and CAMERA PULLS AND SWINGS to bring in the  Easterner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, no. We wasn't playin' fer money.  It was just in fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scully nods, hopefully. The Easterner's reaction to the w "money" is quiet, sick, ineffable contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unconsciously; just  audibly) Oh, yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MOVING CAMERA now favors the Easterner in the THREE S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fun or not, Johnnie was cheating. I  saw him. I know it. I saw him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solemnly) Mister: I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I lie to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for you to tell us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In spite of everything, there is a flicker of amusement i the Easterner over this lulu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrewdly) Ye lied before or now, by yer own  admission. I'll take me pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly) I lied when I kept quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? If ye saw what ye claim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause. CAMERA moves into CLOSE SHOT of the Easterner, l them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Cowardice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't comprehend or believe such an admission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all. (his eyes show us  they still can't  understand; with  self-contempt and  weary patience) We hated the Swede; you believed  Johnnie; you liked me. I wasn't man  enough to make enemies of you. I let  that poor fool fight it out alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks from man to man in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are silent a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Then why're ye tellin' us now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because there's a limit to cowardice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short silence as they ponder that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solemnly) Mister, if you're tellin' the truth,  you're makin' yerself out the  yallerist coward ever I seen.

dialogues.speaker: EASTERNER
dialogues.text: PULLING BACK, as he speaks, into a CLOSE THREE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we're all cowards; that's the  root of the trouble. Johnnie is behind  us; you're afraid to face the truth  about him and your own unfairness;  I'm just the worst of a bad bunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) I s'pose that Swede's your idea of a  hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was the only brave man here  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brave? Him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him? His knees was knockin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (new realizations  breaking open) Sure; he was scared sick. My bet is,  he's been sick all his life, with  cowardice. What a living hell! But I  guess he reached his limit too. He  stood up to it tonight -- worse fear  than we'll ever dream of. And beat  it too -- sure as he beat up Johnnie.  Yes Mr. Scully, he's my idea of a  hero. And whatever becomes of him  now, it's our fault as much as his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Our fault! Why, that feller's just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (catching fire more) Certainly our fault. Good heavens,  we flatter ourselves we're civilized  men... fit to cope with Destiny,  Fate, the Devil Himself. And we come  up against some puzzling minor  disturbance like this Swede, and all  we can do is the worst that's in us. (a strange, almost  clairvoyant bitterness) Oh, we declared ourselves, all  right... as sure as that blue-legged  heron! Yes indeed! We made him what  he's become tonight. We're the ones  who've put him in danger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.; bewildered  scorn) Talk sense, man! Danger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look here. Any man is in danger who  has spent a lifetime in fear and  humiliation, and then suddenly finds  his right to be alive. He's a danger  to others, too. He doesn't know any  better yet how to handle his power,  than a child with a loaded gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies their baffled, hostile faces with deep intensi as the CAMERA PULLS AWAY into a CLOSE THREE SHOT and, wit almost a snarl of impatience over having delayed too long and uselessly, reaches down for his bag. Scully's hand de him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, you: Johnnie's goin'  to have a fair hearin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh by all means for Johnnie! But  don't waste my time with it. I've...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o.s. SOUND of the dining room door opening. Instantly the all become very still and look toward it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNIE
dialogues.text: He limps toward them, washed, but cut and bruised; partly undressed; on his way to bed. As he comes nearer the CAME SWINGS to bring in the other three, MEDIUM CLOSE, favorin Scully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Johnnie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H'lo, Pop. (to the others, with  a sad, brave smile  as he starts past) 'Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gravely) Johnnie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His tone makes Johnnie stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Mr. Blanc has something to say to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cutting across the foregoing line. There is a cold, lightning-like spasm in Johnnie's eyes.  Then he is friendly, tired, ingenuous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leavin' us, Mister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others watch them closely, but watch the Easterner sh than Johnnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (likably) Well what's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very quiet) You cheated, Johnnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling incredulously) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, you cheated. I saw you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnnie looks at him very hard for a moment; then to Scul and the Cowboy, with the smile of a tired good-guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Scully and Cowboy) What is this, a joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dignified, quiet and  reasonable) You must of made a big mistake,  Mister; 'cause I don't cheat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with pathetic  eagerness) Now how about that, Sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (forgivingly) Anybody can make a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For several seconds Johnnie and the Easterner look hard a quietly at each other. Then the Easterner turns to Scully again extending the coins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not unkindly) I owe you this, Mr. Scully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnnie surges toward him but is restrained with curious  ease by the Cowboy and Scully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now none o' that, son. There's been  enough o' that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Scully) You won't take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no answer from Scully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I can't keep it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He quietly lays the coins on the floor at Scully's feet.  Then he wipes the coin-sweat from his palms onto his coat and picks up his bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on a queer, wild  impulse) I'm sorry it isn't thirty pieces of  silver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks away toward the door and out of the sh They watch after him. The Cowboy is utterly baffled by hi remark but Scully calls after him bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now he's sacred into the bargain!

dialogues.speaker: EASTERNER
dialogues.text: This shot cuts across Scully's line. The Easterner is sti walking away from the CAMERA toward the front door. He st and turns, looking from man to man and, at one moment,  directly into the lens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Sacred enough; he's my conscience.  Yours too, if you only knew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away and goes out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLY, JOHNNIE, COWBOY
dialogues.text: o.s. SOUND of the closing door. They watch after him. A  silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Matter with that guy? Gone crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (even more quietly) We can't let him shpread it all over  town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the others start for their coats he squats and, wit sad dignity, starts to pick up the coins. ON HIM, as he d so, SWIFTLY IRIS OUT.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: He emerges from almost pitch darkness into faint visibili into MEDIUM CLOSE UP, looking right and left as he comes the new intersection. His face lights up and he stops in tracks. He is still transcendent, but much more tired tha before. The CAMERA wrenches through an almost 120-degree, streaki turn to the left of him, and stops as abruptly as it star Slant-wise down the side street, fairly distant, there is blur of light through furious snow. A dim sign reads BAR SALOON.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: With a weary, grateful air of seeing home at last, he set down his valise. Then he bends over deep-below-screen and straightens up again and his hands are full of snow, with which, with great simplicity and infinite refreshment, he washes his cut face and hands. Then he flicks and shakes wet from his hands, lifts his cap with one hand and rakes his other hand through his hair, replaces his cap and, hi face alight with anticipation and new hope, almost with l picks up his valise, and bevels off toward the light in a rigid oblique, regardless of drifts, the sidewalk, etc.; CAMERA SWINGING to center on his plodding back.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAR
dialogues.text: (NITE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a clean, well-lighted place; not big. A table at th rear; four men at it: a lawyer, a doctor, a merchant and gambler. We shoot past the Gambler's left shoulder, MEDIUM CLOSE, the Doctor at our left; the Lawyer facing toward the fron of bar, the Merchant on our right. It is self-evident by  their looks that the three we can see are among the most  respectable and well-to-do men in town. Smoothest of all the Lawyer. Of the Gambler we see nothing yet except the  shoulder of his coat and perhaps a rather fine hand with wedding ring on it, and a soberly-jewel-linked cuff, and sleeve of a suit as sober as the others, except it is an  elegant dove-gray. They are all smoking cigars, and there are drinks on the table. The Lawyer is doing all of the  talking, quietly, smoothly and earnestly; looking always  directly into the Gambler's eyes. We soon realize he is t spokesman for the rest, by the way the Doctor gazes into table, nodding now and then, and the Merchant gazes at th Lawyer, nodding more often and more sensitively; and by w he is saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we hardly need to tell  you, Sir, how deeply we regret it:  Even those of us who voted against  you on principle... and it is in our  honorableness and candor due a friend  that I tell you that I was one of  them... (the Merchant is deeply  moved by admiration  for all this) ...even we regretted it most  painfully, perhaps most painfully of  all if I may say so. After all, every  responsible person in Fort Romper,  every self-respecting man in this  part of the State, knows you as a  square gambler. You have never yet  been known to take advantage of any  man who didn't, in every sensible  person's... uh... in the opinion of  every sensible person, richly deserve  it, one might say "ask for it". Your  family life is exemplary. Your  companionship is a pleasure which  all of us hope to share for many  years to come (even more earnestly  and gently) But we do hope you understand, Sir.  After all, (his voice all but  cracks with  earnestness) the Pollywog Club is a pleasure club.  Oh, stakes, perhaps modest stakes,  but among amateurs as it were; (a feeble would-be- charming smile) greenhorns. Of course there isn't a  single member of our little club who  could imagine that you would ever...  ever, well, as it were, uh, well,  violate, uh, take advantage of... (by now he is  thoroughly miserable) ...I do hope you understand me, Sir. (the invisible man  just lets him fry) But a professional gambler, after  all. It's just the principle of the  thing you know. The ap... the  appearance of the thing. No personal  offense in the world. (pause; no help from  the Gambler) (miserably but with  dignity) I do only hope you understand me,  Sir, how very deeply embarrassing  this is for me... for all of us. How  very deeply we regret it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wait, eyes as before. A medium pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.; an even  smoother, gentler  voice, whose icy  central irony totally  escapes them) My dear sir: friends: I wish I might  have saved you this painful  embarrassment. It is because I honor  you as gentlemen and as friends that  I know that you must meet me with  candor, however painful that might  be for you. I am deeply grateful for  that candor. Allow me to meet you  with equal candor. I think I need  say only this: If I were a member of  the Pollywog Club, and my own name  or that of any other professional  gambler were brought to a vote, I  would have acted precisely as you  have done, for precisely the same  reasons, and with precisely the same  sentiments, before, during, and after.  In a word, I would have blackballed  myself from the Pollywog without a  second thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this speech the Doctor and the Merchant have turne their eyes slowly to him in wonder and almost in unbelief and the Lawyer's eyes have stayed on his, burning with a  steadily increasing light of deep emotion. By the end of they are all looking at him practically as if he were Jes and could cook into the bargain. The Lawyer's eyes are brimming; he clears his throat but can't speak yet; the Merchant looks at him and now his ey brim too. At last the Lawyer rises (the others hurriedly  following suit) with his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all choked up; very  quietly) Let us stand, my friends, and drink:  to a gentleman!

dialogues.speaker: THE GAMBLER
dialogues.text: As he rises quickly; he is elegant, histrionic; quietly  dignified, cold as ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a slight bow) To you: gentlemen: and my good  friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all touch glasses and drink with their respective id of 18th century elegance. The Merchant, overwhelmed with  emotion, clearly has the sudden idea of smashing his glas and makes the start of a gesture toward that end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., gently but  alarmed) Hey -- Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Merchant shrivels up with humiliation like a spider i flame; the Gambler's amused delight is beautifully concea He doesn't look around at the barkeeper, but modestly at table. Both others glance sharply at the barkeeper.

dialogues.speaker: BARKEEPER
dialogues.text: From their angle, about halfway up the bar. His forehead still wrinkled with dismay; he is awfully embarrassed to  have spoken so sharp to such respectable folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low voice) 'Scuse me, folks, it just slipped  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between the Lawyer and the Doctor, on the Merchant and th Gambler. The Lawyer, by his slight stiff turn of head awa from the Barkeeper, does not even deign to grant him pard The Gambler is very quiet; an almost tenderly sympathetic smile behind which he is reveling in a cruel delight of i amusement. The Doctor's head rugged and quiet, a little m scraggy looking than before. The Merchant, crumpled with  embarrassment, is just carefully setting down his glass. Lawyer saves the situation virtually unimpaired by bowing slightly and formally to the Gambler, who returns it to t table at large; the Doctor bows, and the Merchant, a trif late; as they sit down, the Lawyer gently, manfully claps the Merchant on the shoulder; a glance from the Merchant spaniel-like gratitude. Their noble mood is addled but no utterly destroyed: they seek to repair it. By the Gambler smile we know exactly the smile, from the Lawyer, which  elicited it; the Merchant is trying to smile too when the is the o.s. SOUND of the front door opening and a stampin in the vestibule between the street door and the swinging doors: all glance toward the door except the Gambler, who watches the Lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Top rim of the bar in r.s. The rim of the bar is exactly  level in perspective and sprouts from exact center of the right edge of the screen. An almost instantaneous shot as the Swede starts coming through the swinging doors.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: At head height, as he comes through. He is as high and gl as before, though slightly less wild; the sudden warmth h him like a shock of peace and good prospect; his face sof and swells; his eyes flick the joint. Again a very brief  shot; he is stepping forward.

dialogues.speaker: THE TABLE
dialogues.text: Faces and eyes just at the end of casually looking at him resuming their private conversation. This shot is as quic as a glance.

dialogues.speaker: BARKEEPER
dialogues.text: At his station near mid-bar. Eyes quick from the table to the Swede, a quick size-up; underplayed and, again, as qu as a glance.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN ON THE SWEDE'S VALISE AND RIGHT FOOT
dialogues.text: He plants his right shoe on the rail; it is clogged with  snow; he stomps and scrapes rather loudly, trying to clea it.

dialogues.speaker: THE TABLE
dialogues.text: Quick, gentlemanly glances of annoyed wondering what it i finding out, gentlemanly ignoring of the boorishness; bac to their muttons.

dialogues.speaker: BARKEEPER
dialogues.text: A sharp little glance toward the table and toward the noi annoyance; a tinge of refinement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Swede gets his foot hung comfortably.

dialogues.speaker: THE SWEDE
dialogues.text: He settles his elbows at the bar. He is tired, almost sle with the sudden warmth; glowing like a stove; still on to of the world but becoming very peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes to Barkeeper) Gimme some whiskey, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Barkeeper walks quietly into the shot with a high-gra Bartender's faintly insolent politeness toward a low-grad customer; he plants a bottle on the bar, a whiskey glass, and a glass of ice-thick water. The Swede pours himself an abnormal portion and drinks it down in three gulps. While the Swede pours and gulps, the Barkeeper, past him, pretty close in the shot, is making pretension of blindness which is the distinction of his c but it can be seen that he is furtively studying the  halfraised bloodstains on the Swede's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indifferently) Pretty bad night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad night. (his meaning is clearly  double and quietly  discourteous: bad  night for you, bud,  that's clear enough)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring more whiskey) Oh, it's good enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He roots under his coat and deep into his britches-pocket slaps down a coin, and tosses off the new drink, eyes  following the Barkeeper.

dialogues.speaker: BARKEEPER
dialogues.text: Putting the coin through a highly-nickeled cash register  with a brilliant clanging of the bell.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: As he finishes his second drink; he is heavier now yet st tremendously elated and at peace with himself: he pivots  eyes and head in a slow benign sweep down the bar and in direction of the table, looking toward the men, o. s., wi towering benign vanity and self-confidence, and friendly  interest. SOUND o.s., of a coin slapped on the bar, rouse him from this boozy musing. CAMERA "adjusts" about as heavily and clumsily as the Swe does, to get the Barkeeper into the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a wave of the hand) Keep it, keep it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a tinge of  sarcasm; the change  is only a nickel) Thank you sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grandly; abstractedly) Buy yourself a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause. The Barkeeper is looking toward the table; the Swede at t Barkeeper. The Swede is trying to cogitate. He's somewhat disappointed; nothing is going as he had wildly imagined would go with people, from now on; but he has just enough sense to realize: after all, this guy doesn't know me for what I am. Better let him in on it a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this isn't too bad weather. It's  good enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (languidly) So? (he drifts a foot or  so away, down bar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Swede is sweating a little; the booze is getting to h now; his breathing is a little heavier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I like this weather. I like it. (nodding heavy time  to his words) It suits me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a short pause) So? (he turns to study  the bar mirror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swede flinches, confused with disappointment and uncertai what to try next, follows his eye along and down the mirr

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE'S REFLECTION IN BAR MIRROR
dialogues.text: Eyes glittering in the scrolled mirror, o.s. SOUND of his heavy breathing. After a few moments of this mirror-gazin the mirror blurs a little and comes as if effortlessly ba into focus; blurs again:

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE FROM ANGLE OF HIS REFLECTION
dialogues.text: He squeezes his eyes tight shut and opens them; his head lower than when we saw it before; he is leaning deep and  heavy on his elbows. Evidently triumph, melancholy, fatig loneliness, the dismay and disappointment of a dream  confronting actuality, all balled up in him, not to menti the whiskey and the warmth, are all hard at work in him,  with all the liabilities a little outweighing. It is in t need for counterbalance that he speaks next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I'll have another drink. (he pours, a heavier  slug than before but  slower and, raising  his glass, needing  company bad but trying  to make it seem  casual, he eyes  Barkeeper o.s.) Have something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks, I'm not drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Swede downs his drink fast but a little more doggedly than before; no real relish for it; while the Barkeeper  studies him more openly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you hurt your face? (a tinge of mild insult  which the Swede misses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud and blustery;  grateful for the  chance) Why, in a fight. I thumped the soul  out of a man down here at Scully's  hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Who was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swede turns quickly.

dialogues.speaker: TABLE FROM SWEDE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: They are all looking at him. CLOSE SHOT -- SWEDE -- FROM SAME ANGLE -- BARKEEPER IN B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnnie Scully. Son of the man what  runs it.

dialogues.speaker: TABLE FROM SWEDE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: Their reaction is not one of overjoy.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: Seeing they are not as impressed as he is, he tries to be it by making it bigger. He is beginning to squint as if s them through a needle eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be pretty near dead for some  weeks, I can tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again he waits a reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking a little  louder) I made a nice thing of him, I did.  He couldn't get up. They...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...had to carry him in the house.  Have a drink?

dialogues.speaker: ON TABLE FROM BEHIND BAR
dialogues.text: The men at the table have in some subtle way encased  themselves in reserve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice neither pleasant  nor unpleasant) No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now none of them look at the Swede. The Swede keeps looki at them. A couple of seconds after the "no thanks" he tur his face into the shot, disappointed, mixed-up and a litt sore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Barkeeper) Come on, have a drink. (he grabs the bottle  and holds it out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA SWINGS losing table and bringing in Barkeeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What... No? Well, have a little one  then. (thick fingers measure  a little one) By Golly, I've whipped a man tonight,  and I want to celebrate. Whipped him  good too. (he turns his head  suddenly again into  hindside close up of  his face. Calls loudly) Gentlemen, have a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table is back in the shot now; only a fragment of the Barkeeper as in the start of the shot. The Doctor looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curtly) Thanks. We don't want any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all conspicuously pay "no attention" to the Swede.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE
dialogues.text: The Swede is still looking toward the table, sore as a bo he ruffles up like a rooster, and explodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly, wavering in  his speech between  Barkeeper and table) Well, it seems I can't get any one  to drink with me in this town. Seems  so, don't it? Well!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssshhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning toward him,  snarling) Say, don't you try to shush me up. I  won't have it. I'm a gentleman, and  I want people to drink with me. And  I want um to drink with me now. (hard fist on the bar) NOW! You understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (callous and sulky) I hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder) Well, listen hard then. See those  men over there? (he flings out a thick  arm) Well, they're gonna drink with me  and don't you forget it! Now you  watch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! This won't do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (already walking;  chops out the words.) Why won't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA is with the Swede, along his right side as he walk He is in pretty large CLOSE UP, filling the right half of the screen, his angry profile almost pushing the right ed of it; the bar streaking past in left half and the Barkee hesitantly hurrying, as he walks fast and drunkenly up to the table. Just as he comes up, lower CAMERA a little to outlifting hand and speed its SWING a little to bring in flash of the men at the table, not getting up, but tighte in their chairs.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDE'S HAND
dialogues.text: In a heavy combination of a clap and a fall, hits the gra shoulder of the man who happens to be nearest him -- the  Gambler's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A diminutive man, twists his head slowly and looks up int the Swede's eyes. From this angle he is all eyes and fore the chin looks weak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From this angle he is all truculent jaw and mouth, little glittering eyes above; apishly small upper half of head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wrathfully) How about this? I asked you to drink  with me. (his eyes flick sorely  and quickly toward  the others)

dialogues.speaker: ON LAWYER AND MERCHANT
dialogues.text: Keeping their seats; looking at the Swede in icy disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly; somewhat  melodiously) My friend, I don't know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (roughly; trying to  smile and be his  idea of "Western"  about non- introductions) Ahh, come on and have a drink!

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, MERCHANT, LAWYER
dialogues.text: All eyes to the Swede, all registering their respective k of well-bred silence

dialogues.speaker: BARKEEPER
dialogues.text: Opposite the table, behind his bar; sprung like a ready  trigger; watching everyone very carefully.

dialogues.speaker: GAMBLER AND SWEDE
dialogues.text: Gambler very low in screen, the Swede very high, past the Doctor in f.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (face still up-turned;  coolly and with mock- kindness but very  firm; very much the  gentleman) Now, my boy, take your hand off my  shoulder and go 'way and mind your  own business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZOOM CAMERA TO EXTREME CLOSE UP OF SWEDE, slanting up at a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What! You won't drink with me, you  little dude? I'll make you then!  I'll make you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the first "I'll make you" he is rapidly stooping; STRE CAMERA DOWN TO EXTREME CLOSE UP of his hands and the Gamb face; the hands are already grabbing him by the throat an dragging him from his chair, over noise of scraped-back c and rising ad libs of Hey! stop! Great Scott! Stop him!

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: Past the three men at the table, centering on the Gambler and the Swede, (SOUND of running Barkeeper and his ad lib o.s.). The three men are rising in their far from rough o halfway ready way, to help; but everything is too fast fo them. The Gambler almost instantly stops resisting the up drag and gets up, throwing the Swede off balance; pivotin as he rises so that he drives the Swede behind the chair  toward the wall opposite the bar; getting under the Swede clumsily placed elbows with his whole left arm and should and lifting as he rises so that the Swede's whole slick a shiny chest and belly of leather coat bulges taut, swolle and shiny as a watermelon, catching highlight from the ba light. Just while it can still be visible before the pivo hides it, he reaches deftly into his trouser pocket and p out something; the snap of a spring and a long blade flic out, flashing the same highlight we have just seen on the Swede's soft belly. SOUNDS of breath drawn in sharp with  horror. The Gambler's arm straightens back, drives forwar a horrifying SOUND as the blade enters the leather (on fa side of fighters from us), and a deep weird groaning grun from the Swede.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost a head taller than the Gambler, whose back is to t shot. The Swede's eyes and mouth are amazingly wide: pain them, but far more, supreme astonishment: childlike. Low in the shot the Gambler, not too easily, (SOUND o.s.) extracts the knife and vanishes out of the shot to the le (we don't see his face) as CAMERA MOVES IN CLOSER ON THE  SWEDE. The Swede is drawing as deep a breath as his lungs can ho eyes and mouth are now even more wide and amazed; then, v long and slow and gentle, incredulous, downward-trailing a damp breath, he utters the Swedish word for "no," which "nej," pronounced 'nay,' in a tone almost beyond sorrow a wonder but partaking of both: he begins to step backward  very slowly, CAMERA gently and implacably following, and  gaining on him a little, very gradually; and still more s to sink; CAMERA ditto: at the end of the "Nay" his chin  trembles a little, the staring eyes alter, one tear runs of each: As the two tears spring out, a SWIFT THRUST OF CAMERA up the eyes -- not too close;

dialogues.speaker: NOT DISSOLVING
dialogues.text: and with great rapidity: The supersonic tone used pianiss at first and steadily increasing to ultimate unbearable  intensity, behind all the shots: likewise a subsonic tone same intensification. In a huge soft radiant CLOSE UP involving munificent crys and mahogany and a spray of potted palmleaves, over dista male cheers and discreet streaming SOUNDS of high grade d music, the Swede and the Gambler, in soup and fish, touch glasses, smiling, courtly; in b.g., the vague-focused hea of the three other men raise glasses; superimposed for a  fraction of the time it takes him to say it, the Barkeepe in smiling CLOSE UP saying, "It's on the house, gentlemen Over brass disc of music of suppertime, very faint, Scull Easterner, Cowboy rush to congratulate him by his tree ju after the fight. Over same music, indoors by the stove, Johnnie, battered sheepish, nods and grins as he lifts the Swede's hand as victor's. Over same music, a little louder, Swede in CLOSE UP, his around Johnnie's shoulders, both faces beaten up, both  grinning as Scully, grinning, in l.s., offers the yellow- brown whiskey bottle. Over the SOUND of transcontinental express, an unknown go looking well-bred blonde woman of a ripe thirty-five lose look of hauteur and smiles up at him promisingly. Over train and disc music a whole parlorfull of floozies negligee hasten, happily, to swarm around an advancing CA A fearsome heavily-mustached blond man in clothes of lowe middle-class Sweden (circa 1860, -- his father), glaring  down into the lens over the SOUND of whipping and child's crying, suddenly smiles beautifully and benignly: total  approval and respect as eyes and lens lift and come level no whipping SOUND: then scowls again. The immense vague tender face of a young woman, shot from the angle and nearness of a baby looking up from the croo of her elbow; over the SOUND of a warm untrained contralt half-humming a lullaby or folksong in a foreign language, she gazes with infinite tenderness and pity into the lens SOUND of impact of a tremendous blow, exploding 398-H int white flash and recovering into a close image of Johnnie  past his still landing fist. Easterner, from earlier, his mouth saying, "I don't under you": but silent. From the Swede's viewpoint: Johnnie does something shady  with the cards. A long line of hard men in a dark bar look up rather  dangerously at the advancing CAMERA over the SOUND of swi doors. CLOSE detail-shot of "The Stag at Bay," very dark. (The  HIGHSOUND is by now very strong; no other SOUNDS.) Then S of child's crying o.s. A little boy pulverizing the face of another little boy w is crying and not hitting back. LOUDEN SOUND of child's  crying; begin lullaby. Face of the Father, closer and fiercer: same SOUNDS. Swede in EXTREME CLOSE UP at the corner of the town in fu magnificence. He is not shouting but add the SOUND of his shout, at a great distance, to the other SOUNDS. The tigerish reflection in the mirror; continue shout and other SOUNDS. Same small boy alone, face beaten, crying: SOUND of cryin Again the huge vague maternal face: silent except for HIG SOUND which is now at its peak!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mouth is almost closed now, his eyes are still wide; slowly, mournfully, wags his head once to and fro as he s the eyes again alter and slowly freeze into an expression unutterable horror, dread, recognition and grief. The fil with this change in eyes, very gradually darkens, by dark printing: the eyes remain fixed on the same o.s. spot, ju off lens, and it is as if they now die and the rest of hi is merely trailing them. CAMERA stops following him: he b against the edge of a little side table; gropes backward  with one hand; fumbles backward between two of the small  tables which line the wall and backs between them to the  bench and slowly lets himself down and, within a second m is still. After a second of this stillness (make it a sto shot and stop the HIGH and LOW SOUNDS) his eyes are still fixed on the same spot.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: The Swede is just out of the shot beyond r.s. The Gambler stands just where we left him; his knife, point downward still in his hand. Only the Doctor moves. After perhaps t seconds of immobility he comes through his friends and pa the Gambler and over to the Swede, CAMERA SWINGING with h SOUND of his shoes very quietly crackling on the sanded f When he gets to the Swede he stands sufficiently between and the Swede that we can't see what he's doing, but it i much -- no need for it to be. Then he straightens up and  turns, with desperate eyes, and goes back past the Gamble and his friends, CAMERA SWINGING, same quiet, sandy SOUND and gets his coat. As he lifts it from the coatrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) O my Gahhd-uh. O my Gahhhd-uh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and starts toward his coat and stumbles against chair as if he were blind. The Lawyer reaches out swiftly as to catch him should he fall; he doesn't; the Lawyer ge pushes-helps him to the coatrack, a hand against his near upper arm; they start getting on their coats. The Lawyer quick, the Merchant clumsy as a child; the Lawyer helps h the Doctor, all set, starts toward the front door.

dialogues.speaker: GAMBLER
dialogues.text: He faces the bar squarely (the Swede is not in the b.g.). is standing very straight and graceful, almost military,  facing the CAMERA, looking to l.s. He is managing this wi terrific effort and his knees are just visibly trembling. SOUND of the Doctor's footsteps; the Gambler's eyes movin steadily with him: he comes across close, l.s. to r.s.; t Gambler's eyes on his. The Doctor doesn't look at him; he so scrawny and rugged with shock and distress he looks si and ten years older. He crosses the shot and out. The  Gambler's eyes very quietly to l.s. again: 3 flicks of hi eyes, to height of the Lawyer, the Merchant and then the  Lawyer again, swinging with them. They enter and cross th shot, side by side; the Merchant on the far side of the L and almost totally obscured by him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half-moaning) O my Gaaahhhdd-uh, my Gaaahhdd-uh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says this about every five seconds from the time he st to his exit, ever more moistly, softly, calflike, never  louder. The Lawyer's head, close, high in screen, is desp icy granite, noble Roman; his eyes, which look straight  forward, unseeing as a statue's. The Gambler's eyes follo as they exit right screen.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: The rim of the bar in the middle of the edge of r.s., and level in perspective. The Lawyer very erect, an arm acros the Merchant's shoulders; the Merchant caved in and stumb as a widow. Now they either just avoid stumbling, or stum brutally against, the Swede's valise; then on, not lookin back, and out the door.

dialogues.speaker: THE GAMBLER
dialogues.text: SOUND of closing door. Very slowly he lifts his knife and looks at it. Again by terrific effort he brings the tremb of the blade down to just perceptible. After a long pause lifts his eyes toward the Barkeeper, o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very quietly) May I have your bar-cloth, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (limply; almost  inaudibly) Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks unsteadily up the bar for the cloth, toward the  edge of the shot, while the Gambler walks even more slowl to the bar; his back, like his front, expressive of terri shock and incredible control.

dialogues.speaker: GAMBLER AND BARKEEPER
dialogues.text: As they converge at the bar, Barkeeper extends the cloth  delicately and the Gambler takes it as delicately. Gamble nods thank you. The Gambler wipes his blade and as he doe that his hands and knees start trembling badly in spite o himself. With an almost suicidal effort he controls the  trembling and makes the faintest beginning of handing the cloth back to the Barkeeper, who winces very faintly; the reaching carefully rather than tossing, he puts the cloth the bar. He folds his knife and puts it in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in an unearthly calm,  dry voice with a  scratchiness  underneath) Charlie, you tell 'em where to find  me. I'll be home, waiting for 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Barkeeper tries to speak; he can't; he nods, then nod again. The Gambler walks into the shot and past the CAMERA and  returns, within a couple of seconds, walking into the sho and away, back-to; his hat is already on; as we first see him he is finishing shrugging into and settling his overc and now, by faint motions of hands and elbows, as he  continues, we know he is buttoning it. It must be clear t though he walks very erect, calm, and even, he is scarcel able to stand up. He takes a long slanting line to avoid valise; rectifies the line the instant he passes it; and out the door. (Under all these exits use SOUND of feet on sanded floor). The Barkeeper, who leaned back against the bar as the Gam went for his coat, stays there very still a moment after door shuts; then up the bar, knees wobbly, a hand on the sustaining him now and then, to the bottle on the bar at Swede's place. He lifts the bottle and the Swede's glass, puts down the glass and drinks from the bottle, deeply. T inevitable violent reaction of a kind of writhing of his  whole interior; a kind of gobbling SOUND. Then a great HU expulsion of breath: then loud deep breathing, stunned ey wandering vacantly. Then we see that they must light on t Swede, o.s., for they stop abruptly, and so does the  breathing. Then after a couple of seconds the breathing b again, great HUHS, but this time much more terrible shatt with shock and with a kind of dry sobbing: an off-balance pump: HUH -- uhhhhh: dead silence: HUH -- uhhhhh: dead  silence. He takes two almost sneaky steps toward the door hand reaching behind and untying his apron: then sprints  ungainly, his apron fouling legs and feet and kicked asid as if it were a snake, with another awful HUH -- uuuhhh  carrying him at high speed through the door. No SOUND of  closing door, but SOUND of the scream of the storm, very down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.; retreating in  the street and muffled  in the storm, bawling,  bestial) Helllllp! Murrrrrder! Helllllp!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD SHOT ON BARE BAR and perspective of its rim, through these lines.

dialogues.speaker: THE WHOLE INTERIOR, (ORTHOCHROMATIC FILM)
dialogues.text: A formal shot from the dead center of the front of the ro a shot modeled on postcards of 1890-1910: our first full  view of the nicest bar in a small town: pathetic but not  completely unsuccessful in its efforts at a kind of barre charm and grace. The sand on the floor in the f.g. is swe in pretty curclicues; these are scuffed along the bar and where the fight took place. HOLD three or four seconds, l enough to register fully the Swede and the cash register, dead-opposite each other, at exact middles of their sides the room. No storm SOUND: pure silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Occupying the whole screen except enough to show a little a contused cheekbone and across it, a crooked rill of dri blood and a snailtrack shining of a not yet dried tear. T eye, if technically possible, is glazing as we watch. Sil

dialogues.speaker: THE CASH REGISTER, (ORTHOCHROMATIC)
dialogues.text: The ornate cast-iron top of the nickel-plated cash regist Its florid shape recalls the florid cornice of the Blue H The cash amount is below-screen. The stamped lettering of the legend is fiercely cold, glittering, massive and hard a little ornate like much of the lettering of the time:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o.s. SOUND of a door opening. HOLD the shot a couple of  seconds after it.

dialogues.speaker: THE EASTERNER
dialogues.text: As he comes through the swinging doors, advances a couple paces, and stops dead in his tracks as his eyes find the  Swede. An impulse to go to him is instantly arrested; it so clear that he is beyond help. Almost unconsciously, he sets down his traveling bag. A freezing anguish of guilt  enters his still face. After a sufficient pause to make clear they did not come  with him, Scully, Johnnie and the Cowboy come in, quietly but winded. They also look, see, and are silent. They try subdue their breathing. They have left the street door op and we can see that there is no more storm or SOUND outsi The Easterner is aware when they come in; we feel that he even knows who they are. But throughout the scene, he nev shifts his eyes from the Swede; and they shift theirs onl rarely. Throughout, they stand behind Easterner. After a considerable silence:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a subdued voice) How did it happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner says nothing. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly too) You ask me, that feller was lookin'  for trouble. An' he sure found himself  a plenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a strange, vague  voice) Looking...? (more firmly, but  very quiet) Like all troubled men. (pause) And we helped him find it, and we  trapped him into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause. The three men behind now glance at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little less subdued) See here, Mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Easterner says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one little thing. Johnnie an'  me live in this town. We don't want  no stories shpread around that ye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as quietly) Go home. Stop worrying. Tell whatever  story you please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ye mane ye -- ye won't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your conscience is your business.  Each one of you. My own is enough  for me to cope with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They linger, unsure and weary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with deep exhausted  bitterness) So just go home now. Leave me alone. (pause) If you please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly and solemnly) We didn't have no part in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three shake their heads, but they don't look at each  other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every sin is a collaboration.  Everybody is responsible for  everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three look unsurely at each other; they are obscurely abashed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a slight gesture  and an almost  inaudible whisper) Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each looks a last time toward the Swede, each in his own  strange way, kind of gloomy, shy, foreboding reproach and resentment; and each, one by one, turns away from the CAM and walks quietly outdoors and out of the shot. We hear o the SOUND of the faint squeaking of their shoes on snow, soon this dies. With the absolute silence an even more fierce and living  quiet intensifies in the Easterner's face and becomes, as well, sorrow, pity, tenderness, a passionate desire for, hopelessness of, expiation. The face rises on a high wave realization, almost transfigured, on the verge, even, of  mysticism, yet iron, virile, tragic -- as, very slowly, h eyes still fixed toward the Swede, he walks into extreme  CLOSE UP and PAST THE CAMERA out of the shot. THE CAMERA HOLDS for a few seconds on the swinging doors, whose subtle breathing stops. Beyond them, through the op door, the air is utterly still.

dialogues.speaker: PICTURE
dialogues.text: Three tiny figures walk in single file down the home stre In the immense silence we can just hear their feet. They in. Light gapes and vanishes, as the door opens and close After a few seconds, light appears in the upstairs window After a few more seconds, the downstairs light goes out.  Then one upstairs light. Then the other. The sky is embla with a freezing virulence of patterned stars. Almost inaudibly, deep in the distance, o.s. SOUND of a t whistle. In the silence after it, the cold stars sharpen; and very slowly, like a prodigious wheel, the whole sky b to turn.
